DISCLAIMER
   The Codified Ordinances and other documents that appear in this FOLIO Infobase
may not reflect the most current legislation adopted by the Municipality. The
Codified Ordinances are provided for informational purposes only and should not be
relied upon as the definitive authority for local legislation. Additionally, the
formatting and pagination of the posted documents vary from the formatting and
pagination of the official copy. The official printed copy of the Codified
Ordinances should be consulted prior to any action being taken.
   For further information regarding the official version of any portion of the
Codified Ordinances in this FOLIO Infobase, please contact the Municipality
directly.
CERTIFICATION
   We, Luke M. Feeney, Mayor, and Kennedy Moss, Council Clerk of the City of
Chillicothe, Ohio, pursuant to provisions of Sections 731.23 and 731.42 of the
Ohio Revised Code, hereby certify that the general and permanent ordinances of
the City of Chillicothe, Ohio, as revised, rearranged, compiled, renumbered as
to sections, titles and chapters and as codified and printed herein in
component codes, are correctly set forth, and constitute the Revised Ordinances
of Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961, effective on and after 12:01 a.m. Eastern Standard
Time, July 1, 1961, and as amended to June 30, 2025.
/s/      Luke Feeney
   Mayor
/s/   Kennedy Moss
   Clerk of Council

PREFACE
   The Revised Ordinances of the City of Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961, also known as
the City Code, is the fourth complete codification of ordinances in the history
of the City. Previous editions were published in 1899, 1928 and 1949.
   This 1961 Edition of the Revised Ordinances is based upon material contained
in the 1949 Code and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted
to December 31, 1960. It also contains a list of special ordinances from 1900
to 1961. The preliminary unit contains a comparative section table showing the
derivation of all sections of the Code. Most sections of the Code have footnote
histories indicating their derivation from the 1949 Code or subsequent
ordinances. Sections without histories contain new material enacted by the
adopting ordinance as provided in Ohio Revised Code 731.23.
   Prior to 1906 ordinances were unnumbered. On January 1, 1906, Ordinance No.
1, New Series (N.S.), was passed and the series concluded with Ordinance No.
3121-58, passed October 16, 1956. All ordinances enacted since the City Charter
became effective on November 14, 1958, are known as the Charter Series (C.S.)
beginning with Ordinance C.S. 1-58, passed November 17, 1958. Beginning January
1, 1965, the City again operates under the Ohio statutory form of government
and ordinances are now numbered consecutively by year, viz. 1965-1.
   The index, contained in the preliminary unit, refers to section numbers of
the Code.
   There are nine component parts or Codes contained in the Revised Ordinances
of Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961. The Codes are subdivided into titles, chapters and
sections. The numbering system follows the general system used in the Ohio
Revised Code in that all Codes, Titles and Chapters are odd numbered so that
there are unassigned numbers which are available for future expansion. Within
chapters, sections may be added either between existing sections by the
addition of a third digit to the right of present numbers or by adding new
numbers in sequence. Penalty sections are designated as          . 99.
   The Editors express their appreciation to William W. Stanhope, Director of
Law, and C.R. Lukens, City Manager, for their invaluable assistance in the
preparation and review of the manuscripts for the Revised Ordinances of the
City of Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961, and to Don. E. Fuller, Esq., for his interest
and cooperation in maintaining the Code to date.
ADOPTING ORDINANCE No. 280-61 C.S.
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE REVISED ORDINANCES OF THE CITY OF CHILLICOTHE, OHIO,
1961, PROVIDING FOR PUBLICATION AT LENGTH IN A CODE OF REVISED ORDINANCES AS
PROVIDED IN SECTION 731.23 OF THE OHIO REVISED CODE AND SECTION 2.19 (2) OF THE
CHARTER OF CHILLICOTHE, OHIO, REPEALING ALL ORDINANCES OR PARTS OF ORDINANCES
IN CONFLICT WITH THE REVISED ORDINANCES OF THE CITY OF CHILLICOTHE, OHIO, 1961,
AND PROVIDING FOR THE COMPILATION INTO PARTS, TITLES, CHAPTERS, TO BE KNOWN AS
(1) THE ADMINISTRATIVE CODE, (3) THE TRAFFIC CODE, (5) THE GENERAL OFFENSES
CODE, (7) BUSINESS REGULATION CODE, (9) STREETS AND PUBLIC SERVICES CODE, (11)
PLANNING AND ZONING CODE, (13) BUILDING CODE AND (15) FIRE PREVENTION CODE.
 
WHEREAS, the Council of the City of Chillicothe, Ohio has had the matter of
codification and general revision of the ordinances before it for some time,
and,
 
WHEREAS, it has heretofore entered into a contract with The Walter H. Drane
Company to publish said codification and,
 
WHEREAS, the codification of said ordinances, together with the new matter to
be adopted, the matters to be amended and those sections to be repealed are
before the Council, NOW, THEREFORE,
 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF CHILLICOTHE, OHIO:
SECTION 1. Under the provisions of Section 2.19 (2) of the City Charter, the
general and permanent ordinances of Chillicothe, Ohio, as amended, are hereby
revised, rearranged, compiled, renumerated as to sections and codified into
parts, titles and chapters designated by odd numbers respectively:
 
PART ONE - ADMINISTRATIVE CODE
 
TITLE ONE - General Provisions. Chapter 101 - Revised Ordinances; Chapter 103 -
Officia1 Standards; Chapter 105 - Wards; Chapter 107 - Civil Defense.
 
TITLE THREE - Administrative Code. Chapter 111 - Council; Clerk of Council;
Chapter 113 - Organization, Policy, Procedures and Penalty; Chapter 115 - City
Manager; Chapter 117 - Department of Law; Chapter 119 - Department of Finance;
Chapter 121- Department of Safety; Chapter 123 - Department of Service; Chapter
125 - Department of Engineering; Chapter 127 - Department of Utilities; Chapter
129 - Department of Parks and Recreation; Chapter 131 - Department of
Personnel; Chapter 133 - Board of Health; Chapter 135 - City Records
Commission; Chapter 137 - Employment Provisions.
 
TITLE FIVE - Judicial. Chapter 151 - Municipal Court; Chapter 153 - City Jail.
PART THREE - TRAFFIC CODE
TITLE ONE - Administration. Chapter 301 - Definitions; Chapter 303 -
Enforcement; Code Application; Impounding; Penalties; Chapter 305 - Traffic
Control Map and File.
 
TITLE THREE - Streets and Traffic Control Devices. Chapter 311 - Streets;
Obstructions and Special Uses; Chapter 313 - Traffic Control Devices.
 
TITLE FIVE - Vehicles. Chapter 331 - Operation Generally; Chapter 333 -
Intoxication; Reckless operation; Speed; Drag Racing; Chapter 335 - Licensing;
Accidents; Chapter 337 - Safety and Equipment; Chapter 339 - Commercial and
Heavy Vehicles.
 
TITLE SEVEN - Parking. Chapter 351 - Parking Regulations; Chapter 353 Parking
Meters; Chapter 355 - Parking Lots.
 
TITLE NINE - Pedestrians and Bicycles. Chapter 371 - Pedestrians; Chapter 373 -
Bicycles and Bicycle Licensing.
PART FIVE - GENERAL OFFENSES CODE
Chapter 503 - Advertising, Billposting and Handbills; Chapter 511 - Animals;
Chapter 523 - Gambling; Chapter 527 - Health Nuisances; Chapter 531 - Indecency
and Unchastity; Chapter 535 - Intoxication and Intoxicating Beverages; Chapter
539 - Larceny and Fraud; Chapter 543 - Law Enforcement; Chapter 547 - Minors'
Curfew; Chapter 551 - Offenses Against Property; Chapter 553 - Offenses Against
the Peace; Chapter 555 - Offenses Against the Person; Chapter 557 - Railroads;
Chapter 563 - Safety; Chapter 567 - Streets and Sidewalks; Chapter 575 -
Vagrants and Suspicious Persons; Chapter 579 - Weapons and Explosives.
PART SEVEN - BUSINESS REGULATION CODE
Chapter 701 - Admissions Tax; Chapter 705 - Boxing and Wrestling; Chapter 709 -
Dance Halls and Dances; Chapter 713 - Exhibitions and Shows; Chapter 717 -
Peddlers and Solicitors; Chapter 721 - Taxicabs; Chapter 725 - Temporary Stores
and Transient Dealers.
PART NINE - STREETS AND PUBLIC SERVICES CODE
TITLE ONE - Streets and Sidewalk Areas. Chapter 901 - Street Openings; Chapter
903 - Sidewalks; Chapter 905 - Curbs, Culverts and Ditches; Chapter 907 -
Trees.
 
TITLE THREE - Public Utilities. Chapter 911 - Sewers; Chapter 913 - Sewer
Rental; Chapter 915 - Water; Chapter 917 - Garbage and Rubbish; Landfill.
PART ELEVEN - PLANNING AND ZONING CODE
TITLE ONE - City Planning. Chapter 1101 - Planning Commission.
 
TITLE THREE - Subdivision Regulations. Chapter 1111 - Plats and Subdivisions;
Chapter 1113 - Design and Layout; Chapter 1115 - Improvements.
 
TITLE FIVE - Zoning Administration. Chapter 1121 - Definitions; Chapter 1123 -
Purpose, Enforcement and Penalty; Chapter 1125 - Board of Zoning Appeals;
Variances.
 
TITLE SEVEN - Zoning Districts; Map. Chapter 1127 - Districts and Map; Chapter
1129 - Changes and Amendments.
 
TITLE NINE - Zoning Use Districts. Chapter 1131 - Residence "A-Suburban"
Districts; Chapter 1133 - Residence "A-Urban" Districts; Chapter 1135 Residence
"B" Districts; Chapter 1137 - Residence "C" Districts; Chapter 1139 - Business
"A" Districts; Chapter 1141 - Business "B" Districts; Chapter 1143 - Industrial
"A" Districts; Chapter 1145 - Industrial "B" Districts.
 
TITLE ELEVEN - Provisions Affecting Use, Structure and Area. Chapter 1151 -
Nonconforming and Existing Uses; Restoration; Chapter 1153 - Yards; Courts;
Heights; Chapter 1155 - Off-street Parking and Loading; Chapter 1157 - Filling
Stations; Garages and Parking Lots; Chapter 1159 - Exceptions and
Modifications. Appendix - Tables.
PART THIRTEEN - BUILDING CoDE
TITLE ONE - Administration; Adoption of Codes. Chapter 1301 - Building
Inspector; Chapter 1303 - Adoption of Underwriters' Building Code; Chapter 1305
- Adoption of Underwriters' Electrical Code; Chapter 1307 - Adoption of the
National Plumbing Code; Chapter 1309 - Fire Limits; Chapter 1311 - Permit Fees
and Certificates of Occupancy; Chapter 1313 - Effective Date; Penalties.
 
TITLE THREE - Local Building Regulations. Chapter 1321 - Signs; Chapter 1323 -
Moving Buildings.
PART FIFTEEN - FIRE PREVENTION CODE
TITLE ONE - Administration. Chapter 1501 - Adoption of National Fire Code;
Chapter 1503 - Enforcement; Modifications; Penalties; Chapter 1505 - Amendments
to National Code.
 
TITLE THREE - Local Provisions. Chapter 1511 - Fire Misdemeanors; Chapter 1513
- Fire Prevention Contracts.
 
Be and the same are hereby adopted.
 
SECTION 2. The general and permanent ordinances of Chillicothe, Ohio, so
revised, rearranged, compiled, renumbered as to sections and codified by The
Walter H. Drane Company, are hereby approved and adopted as printed and
published in book form in the manner approved by Council as the "Revised
ordinances of the City of Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961" and as published and
assembled in book form and certified as correct by the Mayor and the Clerk,
shall be admitted in evidence and accepted by the courts and all persons as to
the existence, effectiveness and regularity of all enactments so published in
such book form as of the effective date of the Revised ordinances of the City
of Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961. One copy of the Revised Ordinances of the City of
Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961, upon certification as to correctness thereof in book
form by the Mayor and the Clerk, shall be attached to this ordinance as part
hereof and filed with the permanent ordinance records.
 
SECTION 3. All of the provisions of the Revised Ordinances of the City of
Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961, shall be in force and effect at, on and after July 1,
1961 and the 1949 Code and all ordinances in force on the date of the passage
of this ordinance in conflict with the Revised Ordinance of the City of
Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961, are hereby repealed from and after July 1, 1961.
 
However, such repeal shall not affect:
 
(1)    Any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture
incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before July 1, 1961.
(2)    Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of
money by or to the City, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the City,
or any evidence of the City's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation
assumed by the City.
(3)    The administrative ordinances or resolutions of Council not in conflict
or inconsistent with the provisions of the revised ordinances.
(4)    Any right or franchise conferred by any ordinance or resolution of
Council on any person or corporation.
(5)    Any ordinance naming, relocating or vacating any street or public way.
(6)    Any ordinance or part thereof providing for salaries or compensation.
(7)    Any prosecution, suit or other proceeding pending, or any judgment
rendered on or prior to July 1, 1961.
(8)    Any ordinance or resolution which may be adopted by Council after
January 1, 1961.
(9)    Zoning Ordinance 1915-49, as amended.
SECTION 4. Wherever in the 1949 Code or in ordinances subsequent thereto up to
an including November 17, 1958 the designation of certain officials has been
changed in the Revised ordinances of the City of Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961, in
order to comply with the provisions of the City Charter, as follows: (1) Mayor
to City Manager; (2) Auditor and/or Treasurer to Director of Finance; and (3)
Solicitor to Director of Law; the new title or designation shall control.
 
SECTION 5. The ordinances including the Revised Ordinances of the City of
Chillicothe, ohio, 1961, have all heretofore been duly adopted and published as
provided by law, or as provided by Section 2.18 and 2.19 of the Charter of the
City of Chillicothe, Ohio, except the following titles, chapters and sections
of which notice of inclusion in the Revised Ordinances of the City of
Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961, is hereby given in accordance with Section 2.19 (2) of
the City Charter, to wit:

TABLES OF SPECIAL ORDINANCES OF CHILLICOTHE
EXPLANATION OF TABLES OF SPECIAL ORDINANCES
   The Revised Ordinances of Chillicothe cover all ordinances of a general and
permanent nature. In addition, the editors have compiled the following listing,
chronologically by subject, of ordinances of a special nature as indicated in
Tables A through K. For detailed study of such ordinances, the users must
consult the full text in the original ordinance books.
Chronologically by Subject
         
Table A -    Franchises
         
Table B -    Easements
         
Table C  -    Vacating of Streets and Alleys
         
Table D -    Dedication of Property
         
Table E -    Sale of Property
         
Table F -    Purchase of Property
         
Table G -    Lease of City Property to Others
         
Table H -    Lease of Property for City Use
         
Table I -    Annexation or Detachment of Territory
         
Table J  -    Change of Street Names
         
Table K -   Zoning Map Changes

REVISED ORDINANCES OF CHILLICOTHE
PART ONE - ADMINISTRATIVE CODE
TITLE ONE - General Provisions
Chap.
101.    Revised Ordinances.

CHAPTER 101
Revised Ordinances
101.01    Designation; how cited.
101.02    Interpretation.
101.03    Separability.
101.04    Headings.
101.05    Reference to other sections.
101.06    Errors and omissions.
101.99   General penalty.
 
101.01 DESIGNATION; HOW CITED.
   The provisions contained in this codification shall constitute "The Revised
Ordinances of Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961", and may be so cited.
   The Revised Ordinances of Chillicothe, Ohio, 1961, or any of its component
codes may be referred to and cited as "the Municipal Code", "this code",
"component Code" or as designated in Section One of the Adopting Ordinance.
   This codification has been enacted by an adopting ordinance under provisions
of Section 2.19(2) of The City Charter.
101.02 INTERPRETATION.
   In the construction of the Revised Ordinances the following rules shall
control, excepting those inconsistent with the manifest intent of Council as
disclosed in a particular provision, section or Code:
 
   (a)   Calendar - Computation of Time. The terms "month" and "year" shall
mean the calendar month or year. The time expressed in days within which an act
is to be done or a period is to expire shall be computed by excluding the first
and including the last day, except if the last be Sunday it shall be excluded.
If the time is expressed in hours, the whole of Sunday shall be excluded.
(Ord. 280-61. Passed 5-17-61.)
 
   (b)    Chief Executive. The "Chief Executive", "Officer" and "Head of the
Administrative Agency" of the City is the Mayor of the City.
(Ord. 26-65. Passed 1-6-65.)
 
   (c)    City. The "City" is the City of Chillicothe.
(Ord. 280-61. Passed 5-17-61.)
 
   (d)    City Council. The "City Council" or "Council" is the legislative body
established pursuant to the authority of Ohio Revised Code Chapter 731.
(Ord. 26-65. Passed 1-6-65.)
 
   (e)    Conjunctions. "And" shall include "or" and "or" shall include "and",
if the sense so requires.
(Ord. 280-61. Passed 5-17-61.)
 
   (f)   Department Heads. "Department heads" shall be those persons appointed
by the Mayor to serve as department heads of the various departments of the
City.
(Ord. 26-65. Passed 1-6-65.)
 
   (g)    Departments. "Departments" shall be those divisions of the City
government, either established by statute, or ordinance, which are headed by a
department head.
(Ord. 26-65. Passed 1-6-65.)
 
   (h)    Gender. Words importing the masculine shall extend and be applied to
the feminine and neuter genders.
 
   (i)    General Rule. Excepting as otherwise provided in this section, words
and phrases shall be construed according to the common usage of language;
provided, however, that technical words and phrases and such others as may have
acquired a special meaning in the law shall be construed according to such
technical or special meaning.
   Whenever in the Revised Ordinances authority is given to an officer or an
act is required to be performed, such authority may be exercised and such act
may be performed, at the instance of such officer, by a deputy or subordinate
unless contrary to law or to the clear intent of any such particular provision.
 
   (j)   Joint Authority. Words giving authority to a board, commission or to
three or more Municipal officers or employees or other persons shall be
construed as giving authority to a majority thereof, unless otherwise
specifically provided.
 
   (k)    Number. Words in the plural shall include the singular and in the
singular shall include the plural number.
 
   (1)    Owner. The word "owner" when applied to property shall include any
part owner, joint owner or tenant in common, of the whole or any part of such
property.
 
   (m)    Person. The word "person" shall extend to and be applied to
associations, clubs, corporations, firms and partnerships, as well as to
individuals.
 
   (n)   Premises. The word "premises" when used as applicable to property
shall extend to and include land and buildings.
 
   (o)    Public authority. The term "public authority" shall extend to and
include the Board of Education of the Municipality, the Municipality, the
County Commissioners, the State of Ohio, the United States of America, and any
duly authorized public official and to any duly constituted Public Authority or
Commission established by Charter, ordinance or law.
 
   (p)    Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal, and
any mixed and lesser estates or interests therein; the words "personal
property" shall include every kind of property except real property; and the
words "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments.
 
   (q)    Reasonable time. In all cases where provision is made for an act to
be done or notice to be given within a reasonable time, it shall be deemed to
mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance of such act
or giving of such notice.
 
   (r)    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" shall mean that portion of the street,
located between the curb line and the line of the next adjacent property
intended for use by pedestrians.
 
   (s)    Street. The word "street" shall be construed to include alleys,
avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, streets and other public ways in the
Municipality.
 
   (t)    Tenant or occupant. The words "tenant" or "occupant" as applied to a
building or land shall extend and be applied to any person holding a written or
oral lease of, or who occupies the whole or any part of a building or land,
alone or with others.
 
   (u)    Tenses. The use of any verb in the present tense shall include the
future.
101.03  SEPARABILITY.
   Each section and each part of each section of the Revised Ordinances is
hereby declared to be an independent section or part of a section and,
notwithstanding any other evidence of legislative intent, it is hereby declared
to be the controlling legislative intent that if any such section or part of a
section, or any provision thereof, or the application thereof to any person or
circumstances, is held to be invalid, the remaining sections or parts of
sections and the application of such provision to any other person or
circumstances, other than those as to which it is held invalid, shall not be
affected thereby, and it is hereby declared to be the legislative intent that
the Revised Ordinances would have been adopted independently of such section,
sections or parts of a section so held to be invalid.
101.04 HEADINGS.
   The headings of the several sections, chapters and titles of the Revised
Ordinances are intended as catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections,
chapters and titles and shall not be deemed to be a part of the sections of
law.
101.05  REFERENCE TO OTHER SECTIONS.
   Whenever in one section reference is made to another section hereof, such
reference shall extend and apply to the section referred to as subsequently
amended, revised, renumbered or recodified unless the subject matter be changed
or materially altered by the amendment or revision.
(1944 Code §4.12.)
101.06 ERRORS AND OMISSIONS.
   Where an error appears consisting of the omission of any word or words
necessary to express the intention of the provisions affected, or where any
word is misspelled or, where a word is used when another word was clearly
intended to express such intent; the word omitted, substituted, or misspelled
shall be corrected so as to conform with the manifest intention of Council and
the provision shall have the same effect as though the correction were
contained in the text as originally passed and published.
(1949 Code §4.18.)
101.99 GENERAL PENALTY.
   Wherever in the Revised Ordinances or in any ordinance heretofore or
hereafter adopted, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful
or an offense or a misdemeanor, or wherever in the Revised Ordinances the doing
of any act is required, or the failure to do any act is declared to be
unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any
such provision of the Revised Ordinances or of any such ordinance is hereby
made a misdemeanor, and any violator, upon conviction by the court, shall be
fined in any amount not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00) or imprisoned not more
than thirty days, or both. Each day any violation of any provision of the
Revised Ordinances shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.
CHAPTER 103
Official Standards
103.01    City seal.
103.02    Official time.
103.03    Official flag.
103.04    Official song.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
State standards of time - see Ohio R. C. 1.04
 
103.01  CITY SEAL.
   The City shall have a seal or coat of arms which shall be the size, shape
and design as follows: The seal shall be circular in form, one and one-half
inches in diameter, and shall contain in a space around the margin thereof the
words "Seal of the City of Chillicothe, founded A. D. 1796. ", and within the
space containing such lettering there shall be the figure of an eagle and
seventeen stars, nine of which shall be on one side and eight on the other side
of the eagle's head; and on the breast of the eagle shall appear in circular
form the great seal of the State of Ohio, which seal represents the sun rising
over Mt. Logan, with the Scioto River flowing on the base thereof, and with a
sheaf of wheat and bundles of arrows in the foreground, which copy of the great
seal shall be surrounded by a margin containing the following words: "Primum
Capitolium Ohioensis 1803."
   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed to cause a drawing to be made of
a seal to meet the requirements of the provisions of this section and to cause
plates to be made of the same for use in lithographing and embossing, and the
seal shall be lithographed or embossed upon all stationery and legal documents
used by any City official.
(1949 Code §2.2.)
103.02  OFFICIAL TIME.
   The official time of the City shall be that established by law for the State
of Ohio.
(Ord. 37-67. Passed 4-19-67.)
103.03 OFFICIAL FLAG.
   (a)    The flag of the City shall be pennant shaped which was taken from the
Ohio flag, which was first used as such at the Buffalo Exposition in 1901, and
adopted by the Legislature as the official flag of Ohio on May 9, 1902.
   The colors will be red, white and blue which were adopted from out national
flag.
   It shall contain a large white triangle, the lines of which represent the
hills and valleys in and around the City, especially Mt. Logan, which forms the
background for the Great Seal of Ohio.
   There will be a circle in the triangle that represents the initial of Ohio,
also the buckeye, the nickname of Ohio. It also represents the rising sun which
is also a part of the Seal of Ohio.
   There will be a broad band across the triangle that represents the Scioto
River, which lies between the City and Mt. Logan.
   There will be a letter "C" in the center of the circle that represents the
City and the star in the center thereof represents the first capital of Ohio,
which was located in Chillicothe.
   (b)    The proportional dimensions of the flag and of its various parts
shall be according to the official design on file in the office of the Director
of Public Service.
(Res. 12-74. Passed 2-11-74.)
103.04 OFFICIAL SONG.
   Council hereby designates and adopts as the official song for the City the
song entitled "Chillicothe", written and composed by J.D. Jewell, a copy of
which is attached to Resolution 13-84 and made a part hereof.
(Res. 13-84. Passed 6-11-84.)

CHAPTER 109
Continuity in Government
109.01    Succession for head of Administrative Agency. (Repealed)
109.02    Succession of authority in departments.
109.03    Departmental duties.
 
109.01  SUCCESSION FOR HEAD OF ADMINISTRATIVE AGENCY. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
109.01 was repealed by Ordinance 29-11.
109.02  SUCCESSION OF AUTHORITY IN DEPARTMENTS.
   The succession of authority in all departments shall be from the department
head to the next assistants, through the person holding the highest appointive
authority within the department, on down to and including the persons holding
the same numerical job designations. The priority of responsibility shall be
determined by the length of service to the City, with those holding the longer
service to be the first to assume the responsibility of the post.
(Ord. 415-62. Passed 7-18-62.)
109.03  DEPARTMENTAL DUTIES.
   (a)    Police Department. The Police Department shall be responsible for the
operation of the emergency communication service, the coordination of all
police activities in the City, emergency actions to protect life and property
and to maintain order and the movement of traffic and evacuees.
   (b)    Fire Department. The Fire Department shall be responsible for the
coordination of all firefighting activities in the City, the handling of rescue
operations and the operation of the fire radio band for emergency radio
communication with the Ross County Sheriff's Department and the Ross County
Firemen's Association.
   (c)    Department of Public Service. The Department of Public Service shall
be responsible for the coordination within the City of all emergency
construction activities and all repair activities relating to the maintenance
of public ways, the river bank, public buildings and the storm and sanitary
sewer systems.
   (d)    Utilities Department. The Utilities Department as a subdepartment of
the Department of Public Service shall be responsible for the protection of the
public water supply and the protection of the sewage disposal plant, and for
the restoration of service and repair of breaks, stoppages and disruption of
such service. The Department is specifically authorized to make temporary
installations and suspend or halt service where necessary, in the interests of
public health, safety and welfare.
   (e)    Engineering Department. The Engineering Department as a subdepartment
of the Department of Public Service shall be responsible for performing
emergency engineering services for other departments and agencies, including
providing information on City utility locations and recording of data on flood
levels and the effects of a disaster on public and other installations, and the
inspection of buildings for occupancy after a disaster.
   (f)    Health Department. The Department of Health shall be responsible for
providing emergency health services for the storage and control of medical
supplies, and the inspection of water supplies and sanitary facilities and
radiological, chemical and biological defense operations and the identification
and care of the injured and dead. Such Department is specifically instructed to
cooperate with both civilian and military authorities in so doing.
   (g)    City Auditor. The office of City Auditor shall be responsible for
setting up accounting procedures to make possible the accurate recording of
emergency expenditures made by the departments.
   (h)    Mayor. The Mayor's office shall be responsible for the coordination
of activities of various departments, and for supplying nonvoluntary personnel
needs of the departments.
   (i)    City Solicitor. The office of City Solicitor shall work in
conjunction with all departments in preparing the necessary orders,
proclamations and legislation necessary to carry out the effective operation of
the City government.
(Ord. 24-65. Passed 1-6-65.)

110.01 COOPERATION AGREEMENT WITH CITY.
   Council hereby authorizes the appropriate City official to enter into an
amended Co-Operation Agreement with the Chillicothe Metropolitan Housing
Authority as follows:
COOPERATION AGREEMENT
   This agreement entered into this 5th day of November, 1990, by and between
the Chillicothe Metropolitan Housing Authority (herein called the "Local
Authority") and the City of Chillicothe (herein called the "Municipality"),
witnesseth:
   In consideration of the mutual covenants hereinafter set forth, the parties
hereto do agree as follows:
   1.    Whenever used in this Agreement:
(a)    The term "project" shall mean any low-rent housing hereafter developed
as an entity by the Local Authority with financial assistance of the United
States of America acting through the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development
(herein called the "Government"); excluding, however, any low-rent housing
project covered by any contract for loans and annual contributions entered into
between the Local Authority and the Government, or its predecessor agencies,
prior to the date of this Agreement.
(b)    The term "taxing body" shall mean the State or any political subdivision
or taxing unit thereof in which a project is situated and which would have
authority to assess or levy real or personal property taxes or to certify such
taxes to a taxing body or public officer to be levied for its use and benefit
with respect to a project if it were not exempt from taxation.
(e)    The term "shelter rent" shall mean the total of all charges to all
tenants of a project for dwelling rents and nondwelling rents (excluding all
other income of such project), less the cost to the Local Authority of all
dwelling and nondwelling utilities.
(d)    The term "slum" shall mean any areas where dwellings predominate which,
by reason of dilapidation, overcrowding, faulty arrangement or design, lack of
ventilation, light or sanitation facilities, or any combination of these
factors, are detrimental to the safety, health or morals.
2.    The Local Authority shall endeavor:
(a)    To secure a contract or contracts with the Government for loans and
annual contributions covering one or more projects comprising approximately 400
units of low-rent housing; and
(b)    To develop and administer such project or projects, each of which shall
be located within the corporate limits of the Municipality. The obligations of
the parties hereto shall apply to each such project.
3.    (a)    Under the constitution and statutes of the State of Ohio, all
projects are exempt from all real and personal property taxes and special
assessments levied or imposed by any taxing body. With respect to any project,
so long as either:
(i)    Such project is owned by a public body or governmental agency and is
used for low-rent housing purposes; or
(ii)    Any contract between the Local Authority and the Government for loans
or annual contributions, or both, in connection with such project remains in
force and effect; or
(iii)    Any bonds issued in connection with such project or any moneys due to
the Government in connection with such project remain unpaid, whichever period
is the longest, the Municipality agrees that it shall not levy or impose any
real or personal property taxes or special assessments upon such project or
upon the Local Authority with respect thereto. During such period, the Local
Authority shall make annual payments (herein called "payments in lieu of
taxes") in lieu of taxes (and special assessments) and in payment for the
public services and facilities from time to time without other cost or charge
for or with respect to such project.
(b)    Each such annual payment in lieu of taxes shall be made after the end of
the fiscal year established for such project, and shall be in an amount equal
to either:
(i)    Ten percent (10%) of the shelter rent charged by the Local Authority in
respect to such project during such fiscal year; or
(ii)    The amount permitted to be paid by applicable State law in effect on
the date such payment is made, whichever amount is the lower.
(c)    The Municipality shall distribute the payments in lieu of taxes among
the taxing bodies in the proportion which the real property taxes which would
have been paid to each taxing body for such year if the project were not exempt
from taxation bears to the total real property taxes which would have been paid
to all of the taxing bodies for such year if the project were not exempt from
taxation; provided, however, that no payment for any year shall be made to any
taxing body in excess of the amount of the real property taxes which would have
been paid to such taxing body for such year if the project were not exempt from
taxation.
4.    The Municipality agrees that, subsequent to the date of initiation (as
defined in the United States Housing Act of 1937, as amended) of each project
and within five years after the completion thereof, or such further period as
may be approved by the Government and in addition to the number of unsafe or
insanitary dwelling units which the Municipality is obligated to eliminate as a
part of the low-rent housing project(s) heretoafter undertaken by the Local
Authority, there has been or will be elimination, as certified by the
Municipality, by demolition, condemnation, effective closing or compulsory
repair or improvement, of unsafe or insanitary dwelling units situated in the
locality or metropolitan area in which such project is located, substantially
equal in number to the number of newly constructed dwelling units provided by
such project; provided, that, where more than one family is living in an unsafe
or insanitary dwelling unit, the elimination of such unit shall count as the
elimination of units equal to the number of families accommodated therein; and
provided, further, that this paragraph 4 shall not apply in the case of:
(i)    Any project developed on the site of a slum cleared subsequent to July
15, 1949, and that the dwelling units eliminated by the clearance of the site
of such project shall not be counted as elimination for any other projects or
any other low-rent housing project; or
(ii)    Any project located in a rural nonfarm or Indian area.
5.    During the period commencing with the date of the acquisition of any part
of the site or sites of any project and continuing so long as either:
(i)    Such project is owned by a public body or governmental agency and is
used for low-rent housing purposes; or
(ii)    Any contract between the Local Authority and the Government for loans
or annual contributions, or both, in connection with such project remains in
force and effect; or
(iii)    Any bonds issued in connection with such project or any moneys due to
the Government in connection with such project remain unpaid, whichever period
is the longest, the Municipality without cost or charge to the Local Authority
or the tenants of such project (other than the payments in lieu of taxes)
shall:
(a)    Furnish or cause to be furnished to the Local Authority and the tenants
of such project public services and facilities of the same character and to the
same extent as are furnished from time to time without cost or charge to other
dwellings and inhabitants in the Municipality;
(b)    Vacate such streets, roads and alleys within the area of such project as
may be necessary in the development thereof, and convey without charge to the
Local Authority such interest as the Municipality may have in such vacated
areas; and, insofar as it is lawfully able to do so without cost or expense to
the Local Authority or to the Municipality, cause to be removed from such
vacated areas, insofar as it may be necessary, all public or private utility
lines and equipment;
(c)    Insofar as the Municipality may lawfully do so:
(i)    Grant such deviations from the building codes of the Municipality as are
reasonable and necessary to promote economy and efficiency in the development
and administration of such project, and at the same time safeguard health and
safety; and
(ii)    Make such changes in any zoning of the site and surrounding territory,
of such project as are reasonable and necessary for the development and
protection of such project and the surrounding territory;
(d)    Accept grants of easements necessary for the development of such
project; and
(e)    Cooperate with the Local Authority by such other lawful action or ways
as the Municipality and the Local Authority may find necessary in connection
with the development and administration of such project.
6.    In respect to any project the Municipality further agrees that within a
reasonable time after receipt of a written request therefor from the Local
Authority:
(a)    It will accept the dedication of all interior streets, roads, alleys and
adjacent sidewalks within the area of such project, together with all storm and
sanitary sewer mains in such dedication areas, after the Local Authority, at
its own expense, has completed the grading, improvement, paving and
installation thereof in accordance with specifications acceptable to the
Municipality;
(b)    It will accept necessary dedications of land for, and will grade,
improve, pave and provide sidewalks for, all streets bounding such project or
necessary to provide adequate access thereto (in consideration whereof the
Local Authority shall pay to the Municipality such amount as would be assessed
against the project site for such work if such site were privately owned); and
(c)    It will provide, or cause to be provided, water mains, and storm and
sanitary sewer mains, leading to such project and serving the bounding streets
thereof (in consideration whereof the Local Authority shall pay to the
Municipality such amount as would be assessed against the project site for such
work if such site were privately owned).
7.    If by reason of the Municipality's failure or refusal to furnish or cause
to be furnished any public services or facilities which it has agreed hereunder
to furnish or to cause to be furnished to the Local Authority or to the tenants
of any project, the Local Authority incurs any expense to obtain such services
or facilities, the Local Authority may deduct the amount of such expense from
any payments in lieu of taxes due or to become due to the Municipality in
respect to any project or any other low-rent Housing projects owned or operated
by the Local Authority.
8.    No cooperation agreement heretofore entered into between the Municipality
and the Local Authority shall be construed to apply to any project covered by
this Agreement.
9.    No member of the governing body of the Municipality or any other public
official of the Municipality who exercises any responsibilities or functions
with respect to any project during his tenure or for one year thereafter shall
have any interest, direct or indirect, in any project or any property included
or planned to be included in any project, or any contracts in connection with
such projects or property. If any such governing body member or such other
public official of the Municipality involuntarily acquires or had acquired
prior to the beginning of his tenure any such interest, he shall immediately
disclose such interest to the Local Authority.
10.    So long as any contract between the Local Authority and the Government
for loans (including preliminary loans) or annual contributions, or both, in
connection with any project remains in force and effect, or so long as any
bonds issued in connection with any project or any moneys due to the Government
in connection with any project remain unpaid, this Agreement shall not be
abrogated, changed, or modified without the consent of the Government. The
privileges and obligations of the Municipality hereunder shall remain in full
force and effect with respect to each project so long as the beneficial title
to such project is held by the Local Authority or by any other public body or
governmental agency, including the Government, authorized by law to engage in
the development or administration of low-rent housing projects. If at any time
the beneficial title to, or possession of, any project is held by such other
public body or governmental agency, including the Government, the provisions
hereof shall inure to the benefit of and may be enforced by, such other public
body or governmental agency, including the Government.
      (Ord. 185-90. Passed 12-27-90.)
110.02  ADOPTION OF COMMUNITY HOUSING IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM (CHIP) POLICIES AND
GUIDELINES.
   (a)    The City hereby adopts the FY'93 Community Housing Improvement
Program Policies and Guidelines in their entirety for the purpose of governing
the City's FY'93 Community Housing Improvement Program. The City also adopts a
related Housing Rehabilitation Manual as may be amended from time to time by
the program administrators, which manual supports and implements the City's
policies and guidelines. A copy of the Rehabilitation Policies and Guidelines
and the Rehabilitation Manual are available for inspection at the Office of
Economic Development.
   (b)    Council, in adopting the Policies and Guidelines and the Manual, does
not relinquish responsibilities to the CHIP Program in its contract with the
Ohio Department of Development in its right to act upon any matter as it deems
necessary to settle disputes or to conduct public meetings concerning the CHIP
Program. Council furthermore reserves the right to grant variances to any of
the program, policies or guidelines contained herein provided such variances
are within the realm of laws, rules and regulations which otherwise govern this
program.
(Ord. 49-94. Passed 6-13-94.)

109.01
 
111.01  MEMBERSHIP; DUTIES; SALARIES.
   (a)   Council shall consist of those persons elected in accordance with the
provisions of the Ohio Revised Code, specifically in accordance with Ohio R.C.
Chapter 731. The duties of Council shall be those established by statute or
ordinance.
   (b)   Each member of Council for the City of Chillicothe shall be paid an
annual salary of $8,362.08 beginning January 1, 2022. The annual salary for
each member of Council shall be increased by one and seventy-five hundredths
percent (1.75%) (Cola increase) per year beginning on January 1, 2023. Such
salaries shall be paid in bi-weekly installments. Single coverage insurance
benefits shall be offered to each Council member with no opt-out payment
option. (Ord. 83-21. Passed 12-27-21.)
111.02  TIME OF MEETINGS.
   (a)   Council shall hold its regular meetings on the second and fourth
Monday of each calendar month at the Council Chamber (Municipal court,
Courtroom No.1) in the City Building located at 26 South Paint Street,
Chillicothe, Ohio. Such meetings shall commence within a reasonable time
following the Invocation or Prayer which may be held at 7:30 p.m., but in no
case shall the meeting commence later than 7:35 p.m.
   (b)   In the event the Council President determines that an emergency
situation exists, the Council President may postpone a regular Council meeting.
An emergency situation may include, but is not limited to, death of a public
official or other City employee, an act or threat of terrorism or violence
toward Council or the City, State, or nation, or existence of a national,
state, or local weather emergency.
   (c)   Upon the determination that an emergency situation exists, the Council
President shall announce the regular meeting is postponed and shall announce a
new date for conducting the meeting, with no less than 24 hours notice thereof
provided to each member and the public. Any meeting postponed pursuant to this
provision shall be held no later than the evening of the following Monday, but
no later than the last day of the calendar month.
(Ord. 43-11. Passed 5-9-11.)
111.03  FIRST MEETINGS.
   The first meeting of the new Council after each election shall be held at 6:
00 p.m. on the first day the Chillicothe Municipal Court is open for business
following the January first holiday. At this first meeting, Council shall elect
a president pro tempore, a clerk, and other employees as may be necessary, and
conduct any Council matters. Newly elected members of Council shall take their
oath of office prior to the first meeting and appropriate times will be
scheduled for this purpose. (Ord. 127-1999. Passed 12-27-99.)
111.04  SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   The Mayor or any three members of Council may call a special meeting upon at
least twenty-four hours' notice to each member, served personally or left at
his or her usual place of residence.
(Ord. 2-58. Passed 11-20-58.)
111.05 COMPELLING ATTENDANCE.
   Any three members of Council may call a meeting and may compel the
attendance of absent members by notice to the absent member delivered at his
place of residence at least twenty-four hours prior to the special meeting.
(Ord. 2468-54. Passed 2-23-54.)
111.06  FAILURE TO ATTEND MEETINGS.
   Any member of Council who fails to attend a regular or special meeting of
Council shall have a proportionate reduction made in his salary for such
nonattendance unless excused by two-thirds of the members elected to Council.
(Ord. 2468-54. Passed 2-23-54.)
111.07 BOND.
   The bond of each member of Council shall be in the sum of five hundred
dollars ($500.00).
(Ord. 2468-54. Passed 2-23-54.)
111.08 CLERK OF COUNCIL; DUTIES.
   (a)   The Clerk of Council shall be the individual chosen by Council
pursuant to Ohio Revised Code Section 731.04.
   (b)   Salary and Bond. The Clerk of Council for the City of Chillicothe
shall be paid an annual salary of $6,489.00, beginning January 1, 2008. The
annual salary for the Clerk of Council shall be increased by three percent (3%)
beginning on January 1, 2012, and shall be increased an additional three
percent (3%) every four years thereafter. Such salary shall be paid in bi-
weekly installments. The Clerk of Council shall furnish bond in the sum of one
thousand dollars ($1,000).
   (c)   Duties. The Clerk of Council shall have the duties provided by statute
and such other duties as may be required by ordinance or resolution, and, in
addition thereto, the following duties:
      (1)   Publish all adopted ordinances, and all legal notices required by
statute, ordinance or resolution.
      (2)   Be the custodian of the official seal of the City.
      (3)   Keep a regular and correct journal of the proceedings of Council.
      (4)   Have the custody of all ordinances and resolutions of the City and
shall carefully record the same in the proper books.
      (5)   Perform such other duties as may be required by Council from time
to time. (Ord. 155-07. Passed 12-20-07.)
111.09 ASSISTANT CLERK OF COUNCIL.
   There is created the position of Assistant to the Clerk of Council. The
duties of the Assistant shall be to serve notices and make his return thereof
for pending improvements in the City. The Assistant Clerk shall receive fifteen
cents (15¢) for each notice served for which the City Auditor is authorized to
draw once against the respective improvement funds.
(Ord. 41-65. Passed 2-17-65.)
111.10 PRESIDENT OF COUNCIL.
   (a)   The President of Council shall be the person elected in accordance
with Ohio Revised Code Section 733.01. The President of Council shall perform
those duties required by statute or ordinance.
   (b)   The President of Council for the City of Chillicothe shall be paid an
annual salary of $9,891.92 beginning January 1, 2022. The annual salary for the
President of Council shall be increased by one and seventy-five hundredths
percent (1.75%) (Cola increase) per year beginning on January 1, 2023. Such
salary shall be paid in bi-weekly installments. Single coverage insurance
benefits shall be offered to the President of Council with no opt-out payment
option. (Ord. 83-21. Passed 12-27-21.)
111.11 STREETSCAPE COMMISSION; CREATION, COMPOSITION AND DUTIES.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: This section was repealed by Ordinance 93-96, passed
September 23, 1996.)
111.12  ORDINANCE AND RESOLUTION SUMMARIES PUBLISHED.
   Council hereby authorizes summaries to be published of ordinances and
resolutions as allowed by Ohio R. C. 731.22, under the following terms and
conditions.
   (a)    The Clerk of Council and Director of Law shall decide within their
discretion which ordinances or resolutions should be summarized and shall
prepare the summarization giving due regard to accuracy and sufficiency.
   (b)    The summary shall be published two times in a newspaper of general
circulation in the City.
   (c)    The publication shall be made in the body type of the paper under
headlines in eighteen point type, which headlines shall specify the nature of
such legislation.
   (d)    The publication shall contain notice that the complete text of each
such ordinance or resolution may be obtained or viewed at the office of the
Clerk of the legislative authority of the municipal corporation and may be
viewed at any other location designated by the legislative authority of the
municipal corporation.
   (e)    The publication shall contain notice that the complete text of each
such ordinance or resolution may be obtained or viewed at 35 South Paint
Street, Chillicothe, Ohio 45601.
   (f)    Upon publication of a summary of an ordinance or resolution in
accordance with this section, the Clerk shall supply a copy of the complete
text of each such ordinance or resolution to any person, upon request, and may
charge a reasonable fee, set by Council at fifty cents ($.50) per page for each
copy supplied. The Clerk shall post a copy of the text in the public area of 35
South Paint Street, Chillicothe, Ohio 45601, for a period of at least ten
business days, and at any other location hereafter designated by Council.
      (Ord. 76-86. Passed 7-14-86.)
111.13  BIDS, QUOTES OR NEGOTIATION REQUIRED FOR FUTURE BOND SALES AND
FINANCIAL CONSULTING.
   Council hereby directs and authorizes that all future bond sales and
utilization of financial consulting services be conducted through the use of
open competitive bidding, negotiated issues or quotes.
(Ord. 23-87. Passed 2-23-87.)
111.14 RULES OF COUNCIL.
   (a)   The “Rules of Council” of the City of Chillicothe, Ohio attached to
Ordinance 73-19 and marked Exhibit A, shall be adopted by the legislative
authority of the City of Chillicothe, Ohio.
   (b)   Current Ordinances 3-13, 44-11, and any other existing Ordinances,
Resolutions or provisions as contained within the Codified Ordinances of the
City of Chillicothe, which are in conflict with the herein defined “Rules of
Council”, are hereby repealed.
   (c)   Council directs that a copy of these “Rules of Council” be kept on
file at the Mayor’s office and shall be made available to the public for their
review.
(Ord. 73-19. Passed 8-26-19.)

114.01 OFFICE OF MAYOR.
   (a)    Salary and Bond. The Mayor for the City of Chillicothe shall be paid
an annual salary of $57,477.44, beginning January 1, 2022. Commencing January
1, 2024, the annual salary for the Mayor shall be increased by one and seventy-
five hundredths percent (1.75%) (Cola increase) per year. Such salary shall be
paid in bi-weekly installments. The Mayor shall furnish bond in the sum of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
(Ord. 83-21. Passed 12-27-21.)
   (b)    Mayor's Secretary. There is hereby established the position of
Mayor's Secretary. The position is established in the unclassified service, and
the Secretary shall be appointed by and shall serve at the pleasure of the
Mayor. The Mayor's Secretary shall be paid bi-weekly under the hours authorized
and the hourly rate set out in Section 15.18 of Ordinance 81-59 as amended.
 
   (c)    Chief of Staff.
      (1)   There is hereby created the position of Chief of Staff. The Chief
of Staff is an appointed, non-classified position and is under the direct
supervision of the Mayor and shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
      (2)    The Chief of Staff is responsible for certain personnel and labor
relations issues as required by the Mayor and acts as a liaison between the
Mayor and all other department heads of the City, City Council and the news
media. The Chief of Staff acts as a representative for the Mayor when needed
and performs other duties as assigned from time to time by the Mayor. The Chief
of Staff or the Mayor’s designee shall serve as purchasing agent and shall
assist the Mayor, and act on his behalf, with respect to approval of all
purchases made for the Mayor or his staff in accordance with Ohio law.
      (3)   The salary of the Chief of Staff shall be an amount to be
determined by the Mayor with the approval of Council. The Chief of Staff shall
be entitled to all fringe and non-economic benefits available by law to
unclassified employees and shall receive pension pick-up.
   (d)    Mayor's Clerk. There is hereby established the position of two
Mayor's Clerks, who shall be in the unclassified service and appointed by and
shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor. The duties of the Clerks shall
include microfilming City records and such other duties as directed by the
Mayor. The Clerks shall be paid biweekly under the hours authorized and the
hourly rate set out in Section 15.18 of Ordinance 81-59, as amended.
   (e)    Human Resources Director.
      (1)   There is hereby created the position of Human Resources Director.
The Director is an appointed, non-classified position and is under the direct
supervision of the Mayor and shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
      (2)   The Director administers personnel functions and labor relations
for the administration. Duties include managing the hiring process, employee
orientation, employee training and development, assistance with EEO programs,
development of job descriptions, and disciplinary actions (hear Loudermill
Predeprivation hearings). The Director represents Management on various
employee related committees, and oversees the City Safety Program, Employee
Assistance Program and health insurance. The Director is under the direct
supervision of the Mayor and performs other duties as assigned by the Mayor.
      (3)   The salary of the Director shall be an amount to be determined by
the Mayor with the approval of Council. The Director shall be entitled to all
fringe and non-economic benefits available by law to unclassified employees and
shall receive pension pick-up.
         (Ord. 120-11. Passed 12-27-11.)
   (f)   Information Technology Specialist.
      (1)   There is hereby created the position of Information Technology
Specialist. The Information Technology Specialist is a non-bargaining,
classified position under the direct supervision of the Mayor and shall serve
at the pleasure of the Mayor.
      (2)   The Information Technology Specialist is responsible for
installing, modifying and repairing computer hardware and software systems, and
providing technical training, advice, and support for various City of
Chillicothe departments, elected officials and employees.
      (3)   The rate of pay of the Information Technology Specialist shall be
an amount to be determined by the Mayor with the approval of Council, and shall
be entitled to the same economic and fringe benefits as other classified non-
exempt positions. (Ord. 15-19. Passed 3-11-19.)
114.02 AS WATER QUALITY MANAGEMENT AGENCY.
   The Mayor is hereby designated as the Water Quality Management Agency of the
Scioto River Basin for purposes of the Clean Water Act of 1977 and is
authorized and directed to perform the duties and functions of such agency.
(Ord. 67-80. Passed 4-28-80.)
114.03  EEO-EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY OFFICER.
   There is hereby created the classified civil service position of EEO-Equal
Employment Opportunity Officer, with the Mayor as the appointing authority.
This position shall replace and supersede the current position of EEO-Employee
Relations Administrator which position is hereby abolished upon the concurrence
of the Civil Service Commission. The job description attached to original
Ordinance 10-88 for the EEO-Equal Employment Opportunity Officer is hereby
adopted by Council, and is certified to the Civil Service Commission for
approval. This position shall be outside all bargaining units, as is the
current position.
(Ord. 10-88. Passed 1-11-88.)
114.04 SALE OF SURPLUS PROPERTY.
   (a)    The appropriate City offices are hereby authorized to sell at public
sale all surplus City property no longer needed for municipal purposes, which
property is listed in the office of the Purchasing Agent.
   (b)    Notice of the intention to make such sale shall be advertised for not
less than two nor more than four consecutive weeks in the Chillicothe Gazette
and then sold to the highest bidder.
   (c)    The proceeds from the sale of the foregoing property shall be
deposited into the proper funds of the City.
(Ord. 111-87. Passed 9-14-87.)
114.05 STATE CONTRACT PARTICIPATION.
   (a)    The Mayor hereby requests authority in the name of the City, to
participate in State contracts which the Department of Administrative Services,
Office of State Purchasing has entered into for the purchase of supplies,
services, equipment and certain material pursuant to Ohio R. C. 125.04.
   (b)    The Mayor is hereby authorized to agree in the name of the City, to
be bound by all contract terms and conditions as the Department of
Administrative Service, Office of State Purchasing prescribes. Such terms and
conditions may include a reasonable fee to cover the administrative costs which
the Department incurs as a result of the City's participation in a contract.
Further, the Mayor does hereby agree to be bound by all such terms and
conditions.
   (c)    The Mayor is hereby authorized to agree in the name of the City to
directly pay the vendor, under each such State contract in which it
participates, for items it receives pursuant to the contract, and the Mayor
does hereby agree to directly pay the vendor.
   (d)    The Clerk is hereby directed to certify and file a copy of this
section with the Office of State Purchasing.
(Ord. 148-86. Passed 12-8-86.)
114.06  DEVELOPMENT DIRECTOR.
   (a)   The Director is an appointed, non-classified position and is under the
direct supervision of the Mayor and shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
   (b)   The Development Director is responsible for economic and community
development; seeking and coordinating grant applications for the City;
assisting the Mayor in maintaining Chillicothe’s leadership position in the
region; manage the City’s homepage and assist with high technology projects;
and work to enhance business, cultural, and tourist relations for job growth.
The Director will maintain professional relationships with local, state and
national development programs and agencies and perform other duties as assigned
by the Mayor.
   (c)   The salary of the Director shall be an amount to be determined by the
Mayor with the approval of Council. The Director shall be entitled to all
fringe and non-economic benefits available by law to unclassified employees and
shall receive pension pick-up.
(Ord. 43-00. Passed 3-27-00.)
114.07  SAFETY-SERVICE DIRECTOR.
   (a)   The Director is an appointed, non-classified position and is under the
direct supervision of the Mayor and shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor.
The Director is responsible for the administration of Public Safety, Service
and Transportation. The Director oversees the administration of the Police and
Fire Departments; the maintenance of varied public infrastructure including
streets, storm drains and traffic control system, and all City buildings and
vehicle maintenance; directs various public services including refuse and
recycling collection, and provides public transit services. This Director
manages hiring and budgets, serves on the Board of Control, develops short and
long-range plans, monitors maintenance programs, assists in development and
management of grants, and performs other duties as assigned by the Mayor.
(Ord. 43-00. Passed 3-27-00.)
   (b)   The Director shall furnish bond in the sum of twenty-five thousand
dollars ($25,000).
(Ord. 6-88. Passed 1-11-88.)
   (c)   The salary of the Director shall be an amount to be determined by the
Mayor with the approval of Council. The Director shall be entitled to all
fringe and non-economic benefits available by law to unclassified employees and
shall receive pension pick-up.
(Ord. 43-00. Passed 3-27-00.)
114.08 RULES TO ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH EEO STANDARDS.
   (a)    The Mayor or his designee are hereby authorized to develop rules and
regulations to ensure compliance with all applicable EEO standards by
contractors involved in projects using City moneys.
   (b)    Any contractor who violates a rule or regulation promulgated pursuant
to subsection (a) hereof shall be subject to: immediate cancellation of all
pending City work; denial of any right to perform any work for the City in the
future involving the use of City funds; or, any combination of these two.
(Ord. 123-88. Passed 8-24-88.)
114.09 EMERGENCY OPERATION PLAN.
   Council hereby approves the City's Emergency Operation Plan. A copy of such
plan is on file in the office of the Mayor and available for inspection.
(Ord. 39-91. Passed 5- 13-91.)

   EDITOR’S NOTE: The Ohio General Assembly by Amended Substitute House Bill
219 effective November 1, 1977 amended various sections of the Ohio Revised
Code to change the name of the chief legal advisor of a city from “Solicitor”
to “Director of Law”. Any reference in the Codified Ordinances to Solicitor
means the Director of Law as changed by the Ohio Legislature.

116.01 OFFICE OF CITY LAW DIRECTOR.
   (a)   Salary and Bond. The Director of Law for the City of Chillicothe shall
be paid an annual salary of $54,636.35, beginning January 1, 2022. Commencing
January 1, 2024, the annual salary for the Law Director shall be increased by
one and seventy-five hundredths percent (1.75%) (Cola increase) per year. Such
salary shall be paid in bi-weekly installments. The Director of Law shall
furnish bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
(Ord. 83-21. Passed 12-27-21.)
116.02 PERSONNEL IN CITY LAW DIRECTOR’S OFFICE.
   (a)   Assistant Law Directors. There are established in the office of the
City Law Director positions of Assistant City Law Directors. Such position
shall be in the unclassified service of the City, and each Assistant City Law
Director shall be appointed and shall serve at the pleasure of the City Law
Director. Assistant City Law Directors shall be attorneys licensed to practice
law in the State of Ohio. The City Law Director is authorized to create the
following positions for personnel identified as Assistant City Law Directors:
   MAXIMUM NUMBER OF PERSONNEL
   4 Assistant City Law Directors
   1 Assistant City Law Director - Office Assistant
   Each position of Assistant City Law Director is considered a part-time
position and shall be paid an annual salary biweekly in accordance with Section
15.18 of Ordinance 81-59, as amended, and shall be entitled to all fringe
benefits (with the exceptions of vacation and sick leave) as other City
employees in the unclassified service as authorized by ordinance. Should an
Assistant City Law Director occupy two Assistant City Law Director positions,
the Assistant City Law Director shall be considered full-time and should have
limited engagement in the private practice of law in the State of Ohio.
   (b)   Office Manager. There is hereby established in the office of City Law
Director, the position of one full-time (40 hours) Office Manager, and such
Office Manager shall be appointed and shall serve at the pleasure of the City
Law Director. Such position shall be in the unclassified service and shall be
entitled to all fringe benefits. The Office Manager shall be paid biweekly
under the hours authorized and the hourly rate set by Council.
   (c)   Director of Law Stenographer. There is established the position of one
full-time (40 hours) Director of Law Stenographer and such stenographer shall
be appointed and shall serve at the pleasure of the City Law Director. Such
position shall be in the unclassified service and shall be entitled to all
fringe benefits. The Director of Law Stenographer shall be paid biweekly under
the hours authorized and at the hourly rate set by Council.
   (d)   Law Director Clerk (Full-Time). There is established the position of
one full-time (40 hours) Law Director Clerk, and such clerk shall be appointed
and shall serve at the pleasure of the City Law Director. Such position shall
be in the unclassified service and shall be entitled to all fringe benefits.
The Law Director Clerk shall be paid biweekly under the hours authorized and at
the hourly rate set by Council.
   (e)   Law Director Clerk (Part-Time). There is established the position of
one part-time (up to sixty (60) hours maximum per two-week pay period) Law
Director Clerk, and such clerk shall be appointed and shall serve at the
pleasure of the City Law Director. Such position shall be in the unclassified
service and shall be entitled only to those benefits required by law. The part-
time Law Director Clerk shall be paid biweekly under the hours authorized and
at the hourly rate set by Council.
(Ord. 69-23. Passed 11-13-23.)

118.01 OFFICE OF CITY TREASURER.
   (a)   Salary and Bond. The Treasurer for the City of Chillicothe shall be
paid an annual salary of $12,405.16, beginning January 1, 2022. The annual
salary for the Treasurer shall be increased by one and seventy-five hundredths
percent (1.75%) (Cola increase) per year. Such salary shall be paid in bi-
weekly installments. The City Treasurer shall furnish bond in the sum of twenty
thousand dollars ($20,000).
(Ord. 83-21. Passed 12-27-21.)
   (b)   Treasurer's Clerk. There is established the position of Treasurer's
Clerk in the unclassified service, and such Clerk shall be appointed by and
shall serve at the pleasure of the City Treasurer. The Treasurer's Clerk shall
be paid biweekly under the hours authorized and at the hourly rate set out in
Section 15.18 of Ordinance 81-59 as amended.
   When the City Treasurer is out of town or sick and therefore is unable to
perform his duties, the Treasurer's Clerk is authorized to sign City checks.
 
   (c)   Deputy Treasurer. There is established the position of Deputy
Treasurer, the sole function of which is to sign checks or financial documents
in the absence of the City Treasurer and/or the Treasurer’s Clerk. The Deputy
Treasurer position shall be held by the current Chairperson of the City Council
Finance Committee. The Deputy Treasurer Position is an unpaid position. The
Deputy Treasurer is authorized to sign City checks and financial documents at
the request of the City Auditor in situations wherein the City Treasurer is
unavailable to sign said checks or financial documents and a signature deadline
exists.
(Ord. 108-14. Passed 12-22-14.)
CHAPTER 119
Treasury Investment Board; Real Estate Appraisal and Option Board
119.01    Treasury Investment Board.
119.02    Real Estate Appraisal and Option Board.
119.03    Investment policy.
 
119.01  TREASURY INVESTMENT BOARD.
   (a)    The Mayor, the City Auditor and the City Solicitor are designated as
the Treasury Investment Board and shall perform such duties as may arise under
the provisions of Ohio Revised Code Sections 731.56 to 731.59, inclusive, and
such duties as may arise under the provisions of this section.
   (b)    Whenever there are monies in the treasury of the City which will not
be required to be used for municipal purposes for a period of six months or
more, such monies may, in lieu of being deposited in a bank, be invested in
accordance with the provisions of Ohio Revised Code Sections 731.56 through
731.59. Investments and securities so purchased shall be sold in accordance
with Ohio Revised Code Section 731.57.
   (c)    The securities so purchased shall be held by any member of the
Federal Reserve System upon issuance, as custodian, under the provisions of
Ohio Revised Code Section 731.59, or by the City Treasurer.
(Ord. 30-65. Passed 1-20-65.)
   (d)    The City Auditor is authorized and directed to apply the following
formula for the distribution of monies resulting from the earnings of the
Treasury investments, in accordance with the following table:
 
   Fund Investing Money      Fund Receiving Credit on Investment Earnings
General Bond Retirement          To General Fund
Special Assessment Bond Retirement    To General Fund
Water Department Revenue          To General Fund
Police Pension             To General Fund
Fire Pension                To General Fund
Plyleys Lane Sanitary Sewer District    To General Fund
Floodwall Account (Account #323)       To General F und
   All City monies shall be invested in the manner required by Ohio R.C.
135.21, 713.56 and 5705.10.
(Ord. 65-89. Passed 6-12-89.)
119.02 REAL ESTATE APPRAISAL AND OPTION BOARD.
   (a)    The Mayor, the City Auditor and the City Solicitor are designated as
the Real Estate Appraisal and Option Board, and shall have the authority to
make appraisals or to retain the services of appraisers and realtors to
appraise land to be acquired by the City. In the event the City desires to have
the services of realtors or appraisers to appraise for acquisition of property
and/or property rights or purchase agreements for such land, the fee schedule
shall be as follows:
      (1)    The schedule for each residential parcel for each appraiser is as
follows:
 
Residential                Per Appraisal
One-family dwelling          150.00
Two-family dwelling          175. 00
Three, four-family dwelling       200.00
More than four-family dwelling    A basic charge of $200.00 plus $25.00 per
unit over four units.
      (2)    The schedule for each commercial parcel for each appraiser shall
be as follows:
         Commercial:
All commercial appraisals shall be done on the basis of a two hundred fifty
dollar ($250.00) charge for the basic appraisal.
In cases involving a mixture of commercial and residential usages in the same
parcel, the fee shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) plus twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) per apartment unit in the building.
      (3)    Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) an hour for any specialty or
industrial property as determined by the Real Estate Appraisal and Option
Board. When an appraisal is authorized under subsection (a)(l) to (3) hereof,
the appraisal shall be in accordance with standards and forms adopted by the
Real Estate Appraisal and Option Board.
      (4)    The schedule for vacant land is as follows:
 
Vacant Land:
   Nonplatted land:    $150.00 per appraisal
   Platted land:       $125.00 plus $25.00 per lot.
   (b)    The Real Estate Appraisal and Option Board shall have the authority
to retain the services of negotiators to negotiate for land needed by the City.
The amount that shall be paid for such negotiator shall be as set forth in the
following schedule:
      (1)    One hundred dollars ($100.00) for each residential parcel for each
realtor or negotiator.
      (2)    One hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each commercial parcel for
each realtor or negotiator.
      (3)    Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per hour for each realtor or
negotiator after four hours of work, not to exceed ten hours per negotiation,
as determined by the Real Estate Appraisal and Option Board.
   (c)    Any appraisal that has been completed by an appraiser in which that
person is requested to go out and make a new appraisal based on additional
factors or information given to the City shall be considered a separate
appraisal and a separate fee in accordance with subsections (a) and (b) shall
be paid for that service.
   (d)   Any work requiring conferences with the City officials after the
appraisal and/or requiring preparation for trial and testimony shall be paid at
a rate not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for each day’s court
testimony and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per hour for pretrial conference
with the attorney or public official.
   (e)   An appraisal assignment shall be completed within thirty days after
the assignment is received unless the assignment is extended for good cause by
the Real Estate Appraisal and Option Board.
(Ord. 69-76. Passed 11-1-76.)
119.03 INVESTMENT POLICY.
   (a)   Council hereby authorizes the establishment of an “Investment Policy”
for the City. This policy is now required under Substitute Senate Bill #81 and
must be filed with the State Auditor’s Office.
   (b)   This policy is to be followed by the Treasury Investment Board of the
City as established in Section
119.01 and is to be executed by the City Auditor.
(Ord. 100-96. Passed 9-23-96.)

120.03 was repealed by Ordinance 42-00.)
120.04 FEDERAL GENERAL REVENUE SHARING TRUST FUND.
   (a)    There is hereby established a special fund to be known as the Federal
General Revenue Sharing Trust Fund under the provisions of Ohio R. C. 5705.12.
   (b)    All monies paid to the City under the State and Local Fiscal
Assistance Act of 1972 shall be credited to such Fund and expended in
accordance with the terms and provisions of such Federal act.
(Ord. 129-72. Passed 11-13-72.)
120.05 SELF-INSURANCE FOR GENERAL LIABILITY.
   (a)    There is hereby established a special account within the City and
administered by the City Auditor's Office for insuring the City against
liability.
   (b)    Each department within the City shall contribute to such insurance
account an amount based seventy-five percent (75%) upon claims made against
each department in the preceding two year period and twenty-five percent (25%)
upon the proportionate share of the department's salary account compared with
the total appropriation for all salaries set or governed by the ordinances of
the City or by Council, including judicial salaries. The foregoing departmental
shares and contributions to the self-insurance account shall be determined by a
committee consisting of the President of Council, the Mayor and the Auditor.
   (c)    The insurance account is to be brought up to a balance of two hundred
thousand dollars ($200,000) annually.
   (d)    Idle funds within such account are to be invested by the City
Treasury Investment Board.
(Ord. 100-85. Passed 9-9-85.)
   (e)    There shall be no claims paid out of the self-insurance account of
the City, without the prior approval and consent of City Council, except the
Self-Insurance Claims Board, consisting of the chairman of the Finance
Committee of Council, the City Auditor and the City Purchasing Agent, whom may
settle and authorize payment of claims under one thousand dollars ($1,000)
administratively, without prior consent of Council, but rendering annual
reports to Council of any such administrative claims settlements. This
subsection (e) shall be effective as to any claims made or arising retroactive
to July 1, 1985.
(Ord. 20-86. Passed 3-24-86.)
120.06 COMPLIANCE WITH STATE AUDITOR INVENTORY PROCEDURES.
   The various City departments and officials are hereby directed to conform to
and comply with the State Auditor requirements with regard to preparation,
keeping and reporting inventories of fixed depreciable assets, fixed
nondepreciable assets and materials and supplies, where required by the State
Auditor.
(Ord. 155-86. Passed 12-23-86.)

   The City Auditor's Office is hereby authorized and directed to institute a

office of the Mayor and office of the City Auditor and available for
