1321.01  APPLICATION.
   The general provisions in this chapter shall apply to all signs except where
specifically provided otherwise.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.02  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    Billboard. A "billboard" is a board panel or tablet used for the
display of poster, printed or painted advertising matters either illuminated or
not illuminated.
   The copy of billboards may be changed without securing a new permit.
However, no structural changes may be made without such permit.
(Ord. 228-60. Passed 11-2-60.)
   (b)    Electric sign. Any "electric sign" within the meaning of this chapter
shall be a sign, the letter, and designs of which are illuminated and/or
outlined by bulbs, neon tubes, or flourescent lamps, or otherwise by the use of
electricity.
   (c)   Ground sign. A "ground sign" is any detached sign which is supported
by uprights or braces in or upon the ground.
   (d)    Grade line. For the purpose of this chapter, the "grade line" shall
be considered as being the ground or surface under the sign. When the surface
is not level, the grade line shall be considered as being the mean difference
in level as may exist under the sign; except that no such average shall be more
than three feet below the highest point upon which such sign is placed. When
the ground upon which a sign is placed is lower than any sidewalk or public
way, such sidewalk or other public way may be considered as the grade at points
within thirty feet of such sidewalk or other public way; except that in no case
shall any part of such sign be more than thirty feet above the ground upon
which it is placed.
   (e)    Outdoor advertising displays. "Outdoor advertising displays" means
any letter, figure, character, mark, plane, joint, marquee sign, design,
poster, pictorial, picture, stroke, stripe, line, trademark, reading matter or
illuminated service, which shall be so constructed, placed, attached, painted,
erected, fastened or manufactured in any manner whatsoever, so that the same
shall be used for the attraction of the public to any place, subject, person,
firm, corporation, public performance, article, machine or merchandise
whatsoever, which are displayed in any manner whatsoever out-of-doors Every
outdoor display shall be classified and conform to the requirements of that
classification as set forth in this chapter.
   (f)    Projecting signs. A "projecting sign" is any sign (except wall signs
defined in subsection (i)) projecting into the line of any street, sidewalk or
alley or other public thoroughfare .
   (g)    Roof sign. A "roof sign" is any sign erected upon the roof of any
building.
   (h)    Temporary sign.
      (1)    A "temporary sign" is any advertising display constructed of cloth
or other light fabric, either with or without frames.
      (2)    Any valance, banner or pennant hung under a marquee, or canopy
with the letters printed or sewed thereon shall not be hung lower than eight
feet above the sidewalk level.
   (i)    Wall sign. A "wall sign" is any sign erected flatly against the wall
of any building.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.03 SIGNS AND BILLBOARDS.
   (a)    Generally. Under the general heading of "signs and billboards" is
included any announcement, declaration, demonstration, display or insignia used
to advertise, or to promote the interests of any person, where the same is
placed in view of the general public, upon the walls of buildings, or upon
constructed surfaces detached from or attached to or supported by buildings or
other surfaces.
   (b)    Exceptions. Signs and billboards shall not be deemed to include the
following:
      (1)    Traffic or other municipal signs, legal notices, railroad crossing
signs and danger signs.
      (2)    Signs advertising the sale, rental or lease of the premises on
which they are erected and not exceeding twelve square feet in area.
      (3)    Signs such as memorial tablets, name of building, date or
erection, use of building, or other signs when built into the walls of the
building as an integral part of the building when constructed of bronze, brass,
glass, marble, stone, aluminum, stainless steel or other similar materials.
      (4)    Signs not in excess of fifteen square feet in area placed upon a
building under construction where such signs designate the architect, engineer
or the general contractor of the work or a subcontractor having a direct
contact with either the general contractor or the owner of the building. These
signs may be placed on fences erected as barriers for the work under
construction, on the temporary building thereof, on the construction canopy or
on the building under construction.
      (5)    Signs erected within any building whether visible to the public or
otherwise.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.04 LICENSE AND PERMITS REQUIRED.
   (a)    No person shall erect, construct, maintain or repair any sign as
defined in any of the provisions of this chapter until he has passed an
examination as prescribed by the Board of Examiners or has been granted a
license as hereinafter provided.
   (b)    No person shall erect, construct, maintain or repair any sign for
which a permit is required without first obtaining a permit therefor from the
Service Director.
   (c)    Owners of signs existing at the time of the passage of this ordinance
(2636-55 passed February 2, 1955) shall be required to obtain a permit therefor
from the Service Director. Such permit shall be issued upon payment of two
dollars ($2.00) and shall be subject to renewal every five years thereafter.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
   (d)    Permits for all conforming signs may be issued upon application to
the Chief Enforcement Official. Permits for nonconforming signs may be issued
only upon approval of the Board of Appeals.
(Ord. 40-80. Passed 2-11-80.)
   (e)    A property owner after obtaining the proper permits may himself
erect, repair or paint a sign no part of which projects over public property.
(Ord. 228-60. Passed 11-2-60.)
1321.05 PERMIT FOR SPECTACULAR SIGNS.
   All permits for spectacular signs shall be issued by the Service Director
upon application therefor, after approval and upon payment of the required
permit fee. The permit to erect or maintain a spectacular sign shall be good
for five years. The Service Director may issue a renewal of the permit issued
hereunder upon the expiration thereof or within thirty days thereafter upon the
payment by the applicant of a renewal fee of two dollars ($2.00) and by
surrendering the old permit, accompanied by satisfactory proof in the form of
an affidavit, that the sign is as safe as when originally licensed and that the
wiring or piping of the same is in good condition. All spectacular signs shall
be constructed of noncombustible materials
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.06 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Application for a license to engage in the business of sign advertising
shall be made to the Chief Enforcement Official in writing. The applicant shall
furnish the Chief Enforcement Official such information as that official may
deem necessary for the proper enforcement and application of this chapter.
(Ord. 40-80. Passed 2-11-80.)
1321.07 FEES AND REGISTRATIONS.
   A fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) is required for the license and each annual
renewal. If the applicant is unsuccessful in passing the examination, all
monies will be refunded.
   All licenses shall expire at midnight, on December 31 of each year.
   All registration and license fees collected under this section shall be paid
into the City Treasury to the credit of the General Fund.
   All applications for license renewals must be made within thirty days of the
expiration date or a new examination is required.
   A license may be issued subject to limitation as to the type of sign for
which it may be used.
(Ord. 59-76. Passed 8-23-76.)
1321.08 QUALIFICATIONS FOR LICENSES.
   (a)    All individual applicants desiring a license to engage in the
business of sign advertising, sign repairing or maintenance must have reached
the age of twenty-one years, and have had three years' experience with a
recognized, reputable concern engaged in the business of sign advertising, or
the equivalent of same.
   (b)    Corporate, partnership, or other firm applicants shall comply with
standards to be promulgated by the Service Director and approved by the Board.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
   (c)    (EDITOR'S NOTE: The provisions of Section
1321.08(c) were repealed by Ordinance 59-76, passed August 23, 1976.)
1321.09 INSURANCE.
   Before the granting of a license, applicants shall file with the Service
Director, certain certificates of insurance, acceptable to the City, providing
indemnity against all claims arising out of the operations of the licensee as
contemplated under such license as follows:
   (a)    Public liability insurance to indemnify the licensee and/or the City,
(the City to be named in the policy as an additional assured) for all claims
upon the assured for damages on account of bodily injuries, including death,
resulting therefrom, accidentally suffered or alleged to have been suffered by
any person, except employees of the licensee, arising out of any operations of
the licensee under the license, and the public liability insurance shall
provide indemnity in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for each
accident resulting in bodily injuries to or death of one person and twenty
thousand dollars ($20,000.00) for each accident resulting in bodily injuries to
or death of more than one person.
   (b)    Property damage insurance to indemnify the licensee and/or the City
for all claims upon the assured for damages on account of the injury to or
destruction of property (other than property owned, leased, occupied, or used
by, or in the care, custody or control of the assured or any of his employees)
resulting from an accident due to or caused by any operations of the licensee
under the license, and the property damage insurance shall provide indemnity in
the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each accident.
   In lieu of the provisions of the foregoing paragraph, the licensee may, at
his option, file with the Service Director, a surety bond in the amount of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) such bond to be written in favor of the City and
issued by a corporate surety company acceptable to the City and providing
indemnity for the City against any and all claims for injury to or destruction
of property resulting from an accident due to or caused by any operations of
the licensee under the license.
   (c)    Workmen's compensation insurance as provided under the Workmen's
Compensation Law of the State, such certificate of insurance to be issued by
the Industrial Commission of Ohio.
   All insurance shall cover the entire period for which the license is issued
and shall provide that in the event of cancellation the insurance shall remain
in full force and effect until the expiration of not less than ten days after
due notice in writing of the cancellation is served upon both the City and the
licensees
   In the event of the cancellation of any policy at any time during the term
of the license, the license shall become automatically revoked as of the date
of the termination of the insurance.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.10  REVOCATION OF LICENSES.
   Any license provided for in this chapter may, at any time, be suspended by
the Chief Enforcement Official for incompetency, fraudulent use thereof and for
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter and the statutes of the
State, until a full and fair hearing, by the Examining Board is had. Such
hearing shall be held within five days of the action to suspend by the Chief
Enforcement Official,
   After the hearing, the Board may order the suspension terminated, may
suspend the license for thirty additional days or may revoke the license for
six months.
   After revocation for any of the causes aforesaid, no license shall be issued
to such party until at least six months have elapsed. In all cases of
revocation, an examination shall be given as in the case of original
application for license.
(Ord. 228-60. Passed 11-2-60; Ord. 40-80. Passed 2-11-80.)
1321.11  FEES FOR ERECTION.
   The fee for permits for erection of all signs as prescribed in this chapter
shall be two dollars ($2.00) for the first fifty square feet or fraction
thereof, and fifty cents ($.50) for each additional twenty-five square feet or
fraction thereof. For the purpose of computing feet, all display surfaces
measured from the outside dimensions shall be included in the square foot area.
The minimum fee for any sign is two dollars ($2.00) and all permits must be
renewed every five years, renewal permits to be available for two dollars
($2.00).
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.12  EXPIRATION OF PERMITS FOR TEMPORARY SIGNS.
   Permits for temporary signs shall expire thirty days after date of issuance
thereof and such signs shall be removed within twenty-four hours after
expiration of such permit, unless such temporary sign pertains to the renting,
leasing, or selling of the premises on which it is erected.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.13  NAME AND PERMIT NUMBER PAINTED ON ALL SIGNS.
   All signs, as defined in this chapter, and subject hereto, shall be marked
plainly with the name of the person maintaining, constructing and/or
maintaining or reconstructing such sign and shall have the building permit
number for the same plainly painted on the sign.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.14 BOARD OF EXAMINERS.
   There shall be an Examining Board for persons engaging in the business of
sign advertising consisting of three members: one member of the Planning
Commission; the Chief Enforcement Official; and the Director of Public Service.
The signed approval of the majority shall constitute approval of an
application.
(Ord. 40-80. Passed 2-11-80.)
1321.15 DUTIES OF THE BOARD OF EXAMINERS.
   It shall be the duty of the Examining Board to examine all applicants for
licenses as to their fitness to engage in the construction and erection of
advertising signs and their general qualifications for supervising such work;
to prescribe the rules and regulations governing such construction and
erection; to grant licenses as applied for to those applicants who shall show
the proper qualifications, after such applicant has paid the prescribed fee and
filed the prescribed bond and insurance required; to revoke such licenses after
good and sufficient cause is shown; and to hear and determine appeals as
hereinafter prescribed.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.16 PROHIBITIONS.
   (a)    Prohibited Manner of Advertisement.
      (1)    No sign painted or printed on paper, muslin, or other fabric,
shall be extended over public property or posted, tacked, or otherwise secured
to any exterior surface of the buildings or other structures, fences, posts,
poles, trees, or the surfaces of other fixed objects except as provided for in
Section
1321.23 et seq.
      (2)    In no case shall a sign be erected or placed over the face of an
existing sign, except by special permission.
 
   (b)    Prohibited Locations.
      (1)    Projecting Signs. No sign shall be erected or placed on any
structure with a projection closer than one foot of the curb line.
      (2)    Signs Obstructing Windows, Doors, or Fire Escapes. No sign shall
be placed or erected across or so as to obstruct in any manner whatsoever any
window, door exit or entrance of, to or from any building whether occupied or
not. No sign of any kind shall be attached to or placed upon a building in such
a manner as to obstruct any fire escape, nor shall any sign be attached to any
fire escape.
      (3)    Interference with Fire Department. No sign shall be constructed,
maintained or erected in any way that will interfere with the proper and
convenient protection of property by the Fire Department or with public safety
or convenience.
      (4)    Signs at Railway Crossing. Whenever a public street is crossed by
a railroad at the same grade level, no person shall erect, construct or
maintain any sign which shall obstruct the line of sight within the area
bounded as follows: Beginning at the intersection of the street property line
(nearest to the proposed sign) and the rail (nearest to the proposed sign)
which crosses the street; thence along the street property line two hundred
feet to a point; thence along a straight line to a point on the rail (on the
same side of the street) four hundred feet distant from the intersection;
thence along the rail to the place of beginning.
Nothing herein shall apply to signboards, sign posts or danger signals required
to be erected and maintained by railway companies under the laws of the State.
This restriction shall not apply at crossings that are protected by gates
operating twenty-four hours every day, but reasonable judgment shall be used in
obstructing the line of sight.
      (5)    Signs Obstructing Traffic Visibility. No sign of any kind shall be
erected in such manner as to obstruct the line of traffic or traffic lights at
intersections.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.17  SIGNS SUBJECT TO MORE THAN ONE CLASSIFICATION.
   Except as hereinafter provided, where a sign is subject to more than one
classification, all regulations governing the various classifications to which
the sign is subject shall be applicable.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.18 EXISTING SIGNS .
   No sign or billboard erected before this ordinance (2636-55) was in effect
shall be repaired or altered unless it be brought into compliance with the
requirements of this chapter. This section shall not prevent repairing or
restoring to a safe condition any part of the structural supports of any sign
or minor alterations of copy or maintenance operations performed thereon.
   Any sign or billboard or any substantial part thereof now existing and which
for any reason or purpose is blown down, destroyed, taken down or removed,
shall not be re-erected, reconstructed, rebuilt or relocated unless it shall be
made to comply with this chapter and the proper permits obtained.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.19 MOVING SIGNS.
   If an existing sign is moved and erected on the same premises for which the
original permit was issued, no further permit shall be required, but the sign
when erected must conform to the provisions of this chapter governing erection
and construction of signs. If moved to a new location, it shall be classed as a
new sign and shall conform to all the rules governing this type of sign and a
new permit shall be obtained.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.20  CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)    Generally. All signs shall be constructed of approved materials as
hereinafter prescribed and no sign shall be constructed or established until
after the construction, support and bracing have been approved by the Service
Director. All signs shall be of such construction, support and bracing that
will safely support the weight of the sign and resist a wind pressure of thirty
pounds to the square foot.
   (b)    Wall Signs. Wall signs shall not be constructed of wood or other
combustible materials.
 
   (c)    Metal Signs. A metal sign shall have its face or background
constructed of metal not lighter than No. 28 gauge, which may cover a wood
frame and may be provided with letters, figures, characters, borders or
moldings of wood.
   (d)    Glass and Plastic Signs. The glass used in signs shall be double
strength glass. Before any permit can be issued for any glass and/or plastic
sign, the construction of same must be approved by the Service Director.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.21  MAINTENANCE.
   Owners of signs are herein required to maintain such signs and structural
supports thereof in sound and presentable condition.
   Upon failure on the part of the owner to comply with these provisions, the
Service Director shall have the authority to cause the removal of the signs at
the expense of the owner. The Service Director shall notify the owner at least
three days prior to each removal, and the owner may within three days, file an
appeal in writing with the Board of Examiners, from the notification, and the
filing of such appeal shall prevent any further action being taken by the
Service Director for the removal of such sign until final action by the Board
of Examiners on the appeal. (Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.22  ILLUMINATED SIGNS.
   All electric and neon signs shall be constructed of materials approved by
the National Board of Fire Underwriters.
   All signs illuminated by electricity, including those made to be illuminated
by projected lights shall have connections made to the main wiring system in a
safe manner, to be approved by the Service Director, and the electrical part of
the sign shall not be operated until such approval has been rendered.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.23 MAXIMUM SIZE OF TEMPORARY SIGNS.
   No temporary sign shall exceed four feet in height.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.24 TEMPORARY SIGNS, PROJECTION OVER SIDEWALK.
   No temporary sign shall extend into the line of any street, sidewalk, alley,
or other public thoroughfare; provided, however, that this provision shall not
apply to a convention of twenty or more delegates, who shall have occasion to
hold a formal and special assembly of delegates at a convention to be held
within the City.
   The Service Director is authorized to permit temporary banners to be erected
advertising conventions, providing the temporary banners are erected in a safe
manner to the satisfaction of the Service Director.
   Permission to erect temporary banners advertising conventions shall not be
granted for a period to exceed two weeks, and within twenty-four hours after
the termination of the permits the banners shall be required to be removed at
the expense of the party obtaining the permit to erect them.
   Nothing in this section shall affect signs permitted by the Service Director
which publicize events contributing to the public health, safety, welfare or
betterment of the people of the City.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.25  NUMBER OF TEMPORARY SIGNS RESTRICTED.
   Not more than one such temporary sign shall be permitted per occupant on any
street frontage for each story occupied.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.26 MAXIMUM SIZE OF PROJECTING SIGNS.
   No projecting sign g reater than fifty square feet in area may be erected
anywhere.
(Ord. 228-60. Passed 11-2-60.)
1321.27 PROJECTION OVER PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   No projecting sign shall be supported on public property.
   All projecting signs may extend into the line of any street, sidewalk, alley
or other public thoroughfare from the face of the building or structure to
which it is attached as follows:
   (a)    Electric signs may have a twelve foot extension over public property,
with the inside edge of the sign not more than twenty-four inches from the
street lot line.
   (b)    Glass box signs may have a four foot extension and be not more than
thirty inches in height, measuring glass only.
   (c)    All other signs may have a four foot extension and be not more than
eight feet in height.
(Ord. 228-60. Passed 11-2-60.)
1321.28 HEIGHT OF PROJECTING SIGN ABOVE PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   (a)    No projecting sign shall be less than eight feet above the surface of
a sidewalk.
   (b)    No projecting sign shall be less than fourteen feet above the surface
of a street where there is no sidewalk.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.29 NUMBER OF PROJECTING SIGNS PERMITTED.
   Only one projecting sign shall be allowed each tenant on each street front,
except by special permission from the Planning Commission.
(Ord. 228-60. Passed 11-2-60.)
1321.30  EXCEPTIONS TO PROJECTING SIGNS ABOVE PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   The provisions of Sections
1321.27 and
1321.28 shall not apply to signs constructed as an integral part on the sides
of fireproof canopies, which have a clearance of twelve feet above the sidewalk
provided such signs are constructed of metal material.
   No such sign shall at any point extend beyond the outer face of the canopy
or exceed a height of six feet, measured from the lower facial line.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.31  WALL SIGN, PROJECTION OVER PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   No wall sign shall extend into the line of any street, sidewalk, alley or
other public thoroughfare for a distance greater than twelve inches.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.32 WALL SIGN, PROJECTION ABOVE ROOF.
   No wall sign or part of such wall sign shall project above the top of the
wall to which it is attached unless it is firmly secured as required by the
Service Director.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.33 HEIGHT OF WALL SIGN ABOVE SIDEWALK .
   No wall sign shall be erected with the bottom edge thereof less than eight
feet above the sidewalk except for signs projecting not over three inches
beyond the face of a building over public property.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.34 ORNAMENTAL FEATURES OF BUILDINGS COVERED BY WALL SIGNS.
   In all cases a wall sign shall be set flatly against the building and shall
not cover the ornamental features of a building except by special permission
from the Service Director.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.35 HEIGHT OF ROOF SIGN.
   No roof sign shall be erected to a height of more than twenty-five feet
above the roof of any building.
   An ornament or roof sign may extend above this height if special permission
is granted by the Service Director.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.36 EXTENSION BEYOND EDGE OF ROOF.
   No roof sign shall extend beyond the edge of the roof in any direction.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.37 ROOF SIGN; SETBACK FROM STREET WALL.
   No roof sign shall be erected closer than four feet to any wall on a street
front.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.38  INCOMBUSTIBLE CONSTRUCTION OF ROOF SIGN.
   All roof signs, including all supports and bracing, shall be constructed of
metal or other noncombustible material.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.39  HEIGHT OF GROUND SIGN.
   No ground sign shall at any point be more than twenty-two feet, nor less
than two feet above the grade line and shall be properly supported and braced.
The space between the bottom of the sign and the grade shall be open except for
lattice. Lattice shall be open spaces aggregating at least fifty percent of the
total area uniformly distributed over such area.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.40 MAXIMUM LENGTH OF GROUND SIGN.
   No ground signs shall exceed seventy-five feet in length.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.41 SETBACK OF GROUND SIGN.
   No ground sign shall be placed in front of the building setback lines as
provided in the Planning and Zoning Code.
   Where new buildings are erected, existing ground signs shall be setback to
the building line.
   Ground signs of six square feet or less supported by ornamental posts upon
private property and conforming to the zoning requirements as to size, may be
placed between the property line and the building setback line.
(Ord. 228-60. Passed 11-2-60.)
1321.42  GROUND SIGNS, SIDE YARD CLEARANCE.
   All ground signs shall have a side yard clearance of at least five feet from
buildings and lot lines.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.43 DISTANCE REQUIRED BETWEEN GROUND SIGNS.
   There shall be an open space of not less than two feet between any two
ground signs, measured longitudinally parallel to the plane of the sign.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.44 MAINTENANCE OF GROUNDS .
   The premises on which ground signs are erected shall be kept free of all
debris, long grass and weeds by the owner of the sign.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.45  BILLBOARDS CLASSIFIED.
   Billboards shall be classed as wall signs, roof signs or ground signs, and
shall comply with the respective regulations governing those classifications
and the provisions following in this chapter.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.46  BILLBOARDS PROHIBITED IN RESIDENCE DISTRICTS.
   No billboard shall be erected or maintained within any residence district as
defined in the Zoning Code, which does not conform to the requirements for that
residence district under the Zoning Code.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.47  BILLBOARDS, PROPERTY MAINTENANCE.
   No person maintaining a billboard shall scatter, daub, or leave any paste,
glue, or like substance used for affixing bills, or scatter or throw any old
bills or waste materials removed from billboards, on the premises, public
street or way.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.48 CONSTRUCTION OF MARQUEE SIGNS.
   Marquee signs shall be constructed entirely of metal or noncombustible
material and may be attached to, or hung from a marquee, and such signs when
hung from a marquee shall be at least nine feet at its lowest level above the
sidewalk or ground level and further, no such sign shall extend outside the
line of such marquee. Marquee signs may be attached to the sides and front of a
marquee, and such sign may extend the entire length and width of the marquee,
provided such sign does not extend more than six feet above, nor one foot below
such marquee but under no circumstances, shall the sign have a vertical
dimension greater than six feet.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.49 SPECIAL PROVISIONS.
   (a)    Real estate signs advertising the sale, rental or lease of the
premises on which they are maintained. Such signs shall be unlighted and not
over twenty-five square feet in area, except as may be authorized by the Board
of Appeals, and shall set back from every street lot line at least twenty feet
.
   (b)    Announcement or professional signs over one square foot in area.
Signs or bulletin boards not over twelve square feet in area for the exclusive
use of a church, school, community center, or other public or institutional
building which, if not attached flat against a building, shall be distant at
least twelve feet from all street lines; wall signs pertaining to a
nonconforming use on the same premises as such use and not exceeding in the
aggregate twenty square feet in area or five feet in one dimension; projecting
signs pertaining to a nonconforming use on the same premises as such use and
not exceeding in the aggregate twelve square feet in area, subject to approval
of the Board of Appeals. Provided, however, only one wall and one projecting
sign may be erected on any one premises; existing nonconforming signs must meet
requirements as to number but not as to size provided all other requirements
are met. All such signs may be illuminated, provided the source of light is not
visible.
(Ord. 228-60. Passed 11-2-60.)
1321.50  LADDER ON SIDEWALK .
   Any person who shall cause any ladder to be erected on public property for
any purpose shall as a safety precaution, cause same to be safely secured and
adequately marked
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
1321.51  SIGNS IN INDUSTRIAL AREAS.
   The number of signs or the size of signs in industrial zoning is not
restricted except as to height, setbacks and clearances.
(Ord. 228-60. Passed 11-2-60.)
1321.52 LIABILITY FOR DAMAGES.
   This chapter shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the liability
or responsibility of any party owning, operating, controlling or installing any
sign advertising or the construction or erection thereof for damages to persons
or property caused by any defect therein, nor shall the City be held as
assuming any such liability by reason of the inspection authorized herein.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
 
1321.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisoned for not more than three
months, or both. Each and every day or portion thereof during which any
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter is committed, continued or
permitted shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 2636-55. Passed 2-2-55.)
CHAPTER 1322
Wireless Telecommunication Facilities and Towers
1322.01   Intent and purpose.
1322.02   Definitions.
1322.03   Application.
1322.04   Conditional use.
1322.05   Regulations.
1322.06   Approval.
 
1322.01 INTENT AND PURPOSE.
   The purpose and intent of this chapter is to regulate the placement,
construction and modifications of Wireless Telecommunication Facilities and
Towers located within the City, in order to protect the health, safety and
welfare of the public, while at the same time not unreasonably interfering with
the development of the competitive wireless telecommunications market place.
(Ord. 42-98. Passed 4-27-98.)
1322.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following words and their derivatives
have the meanings defined below.
   (a)   “Antenna support structure” means any building or other structure
other than a Tower which can be used for location of Wireless
Telecommunications Facilities.
   (b)   “Monopole” means a support structure constructed of a single, self-
supporting hollow metal tube securely anchored to a foundation.
   (c)   “Open space” means land devoted to conservation or recreational
purposes and/or land designated by a municipality to remain undeveloped (may be
specified on a zoning map).
   (d)   “Tower” means a self-supporting lattice, guyed or monopole structure
constructed from grade which supports Wireless Telecommunications Facilities.
The term Tower shall not include amateur radio operators’ equipment, as
licensed by the FCC.
   (e)   “Viewshed” means the area surrounding a Wireless Telecommunications
Facility or Antenna Support Structure, within which the Facility or Structure
is visible from street level.
   (f)   “Wireless Telecommunication Facilities” means any cables, wires,
lines, wave guides, antennas and any other equipment or facilities associated
with the transmission or reception of communications as authorized by the FCC
which a person seeks to locate or has installed upon a tower or Antenna Support
Structure. However, the term Wireless Telecommunications Facilities shall not
include:
      (1)   Any satellite earth station antenna two meters in diameter or less
which are located in an area zoned industrial or commercial;
      (2)   Any satellite earth station antenna one meter or less in diameter,
regardless of zoning category;
      (3)   Antennas used by amateur radio operators are excluded from this
definition.
         (Ord. 42-98. Passed 4-27-98.)
1322.03 APPLICATION.
   This chapter shall apply to all construction of Wireless Telecommunication
Facilities, Antenna Support Structures, and Towers within the City of
Chillicothe, Ohio.
(Ord. 42-98. Passed 4-27-98.)
1322.04 CONDITIONAL USE.
   The construction of Wireless Telecommunication Facilities, Antenna Support
Structures, and Towers, within the City of Chillicothe shall be considered a
conditional use subject to approval by application through the Chillicothe
Planning Commission.
(Ord. 42-98. Passed 4-27-98.)
1322.05 REGULATIONS.
   The following regulations shall be examined by the Chillicothe Planning
Commission in ruling upon the application for construction of Wireless
Telecommunication Facilities, Antenna Support Structures, and Towers, within
the City of Chillicothe.
   (a)   When the proposed Wireless Telecommunications Facility or Antenna
Support Structure is to include a new Tower, a plot plan at a scale of not less
than one inch equals 100 feet shall be submitted to the City Engineer’s Office
(attn: Building Inspector). This plot plan shall indicate all building uses
within 200 feet of the proposed facility. Aerial photos and/or renderings may
augment the plot plan.
   (b)   A diagram or map showing the viewshed of the proposed Wireless
Telecommunications Facilities or Antenna Support Structure shall be provided.
   (c)   Photosimulations of the proposed facility from effected residential
properties and public rights-of-way at varying distances shall be provided.
   (d)   The location of the Tower and Equipment Shelter and Antenna Support
Structure shall comply with all natural resource protection standards
established in the Zoning Code of the Codified Ordinances of Chillicothe, Ohio,
including those for flood plain, wetlands and steep slopes.
   (e)   Security fencing eight feet in height shall surround the Tower,
Equipment Shelter and any guy wires, either completely or individually as
determined by the Planning Commission. No barbed or razor wire shall be
permitted in residential neighborhoods. The City and co-locators shall have
reasonable access. No fence shall be required on top of a building or other
structure if access to the roof or top of the structure or building is secure.
   (f)   Buffer plantings may be located around the perimeter of the security
fence as deemed appropriate by the City Planning Commission.
   (g)   Existing vegetation (trees and shrubs) shall be preserved to the
maximum extent possible.
   (h)   Compliance with co-location requirements.
   (i)   Any application to locate a Wireless Telecommunications Facility on a
building or structure that is listed on a historic register, or is in a
historic district, shall be subject first to review by the City’s Design Review
Board.
   (j)   The Tower shall be painted a non-contrasting gray or similar color
minimizing its visibility, unless otherwise required by the Federal
Communications Commission (FCC) or Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).
Except for Tower or Monopole structures, all appurtenances shall be
aesthetically and architecturally compatible with the surrounding environment.
   (k)   No advertising is permitted anywhere on the Wireless
Telecommunications Facility, with the exception of identification signage.
      (Ord. 42-98. Passed 4-27-98.)
1322.06 APPROVAL.
   The Chillicothe Planning Commission shall either approve, approve with
stipulations, or disapprove the application to construct a Wireless
Telecommunications Facilities, Antenna Support Structures and Towers. The
Chillicothe Planning Commission shall submit its decision to City Council for
final approval.
(Ord. 42-98. Passed 4-27-98.)
CHAPTER 1323
Moving Buildings
1323.01    Moving permit required.
1323.02    Issuance of permit.
1323.03    Responsibility of permittee.
1323.04    Permit fees.
 
1323.01 MOVING PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall move or cause to be moved, any structure, building or other
thing not permitted on the highway by Part Three - The Traffic Code, or the
Ohio Revised Code, over the streets, highways or alleys of the City, from any
one location to any other location without a permit.
(Ord. 2881-56. Passed 7-18-56.)
1323.02 ISSUANCE OF PERMIT.
   The Service Director is authorized to issue a permit for such purposes upon
proper application of the parties concerned. Any such moving shall be routed by
the proper City officials to avoid traffic congestion over the routes
determined to be in the best interest of the City.
(Ord. 2881-56. Passed 7-18-56.)
1323.03  RESPONSIBILITY OF PERMITTEE.
   The applicant for the permit must assume responsibility for the removal of
tree limbs, branches, wires, lights and other impediments and shall reimburse
the City for any damage caused to the streets, and shall further save the City
harmless from any and all damages to private property caused by such moving.
(Ord. 2881-56. Passed 7-18-56.)
1323.04  PERMIT FEE.
   The fee for a permit to move a building or structure under the provisions of
the foregoing section, shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for the permit. Where a
rerouting of traffic is involved, the fee for the permit shall be fifty dollars
($50.00) for each day that the permit is required.
(Ord. 2881-56. Passed 7-18-56.)
CHAPTER 1325
Awnings
1325.01    Definition.
1325.02    Permit application.
1325.03    Approval and issuance of permit; fee.
1325.04    Specifications for erection of awnings.
1325.99    Penalty.
 
1325.01  DEFINITION.
   As used herein, "awning or awnings" means the projection of a building
material from a building over a City right of way, except a sign.
(Ord. 94-68. Passed 12-23-68.)
1325.02 PERMIT APPLICATION.
   All persons, firms or corporations desiring to erect awnings over the City
property shall make an application to the Chief Enforcement Official of the
City in writing, attaching a sketch, blueprint or plan of their proposed
construction showing specifications, materials to be used, heights and areas of
the City property to be covered and such other information as may be required
by the Chief Enforcement Official.
(Ord. 40-80. Passed 2-11-80.)
1325.03 APPROVAL AND ISSUANCE OF PERMIT; FEE.
   Upon approval of such application the Chief Enforcement Official shall issue
a permit for the construction of such awning or awnings upon the locations
approved and only after payment to the Chief Enforcement Official of a permit
fee of two dollars ($2.00) for each location approved.
(Ord. 40-80. Passed 2-11-80.)
1325.04 SPECIFICATIONS FOR ERECTION OF AWNINGS.
   The minimum clearance above the sidewalk for an awning is eight feet. The
maximum projection into a public driveway of an awning shall not exceed two-
thirds of the distance from the property line to the curb line, or fourteen
feet, whichever is greater. The maximum height of an awning shall not exceed
thirteen feet above the sidewalk, excluding guy lines or supporting braces.
(Ord. 94-68. Passed 12-23-68.)
1325.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for each
offense.
(Ord. 94-68. Passed 12-23-68.)
CHAPTER 1327
Abandoned Service Stations
1327.01    Definition.
1327.02    Nuisance; abatement.
1327.03    Notice to abate abandoned condition.
1327.04    Remedy by Chief Enforcement Official for noncompliance.
1327.05    Appeals; hearing.
1327.06    Inoperative service stations; defined and regulated.
 
1327.01  DEFINITION.
   "Abandoned service station" means a service station which has not been
operated for at least a period of six consecutive months.
(Ord. 81-70. Passed 11-9-70.)
1327.02 NUISANCE; ABATEMENT.
   If any service station becomes abandoned, such service station shall be
presumed to be a nuisance affecting or endangering surrounding property values
and a detriment to the public health, safety, convenience, comfort, property or
general welfare of the community, and shall be abated.
(Ord. 81-70. Passed 11-9-70.)
1327.03 NOTICE TO ABATE ABANDONED CONDITION.
   Wherever the Chief Enforcement Official finds any service station to be
abandoned within the meaning of Section
1327.01, he shall give notice in the same manner as a service of summons in
civil cases or by certified mail addressed to the owner of record of the
premises at his last known address or to the address to which tax bills are
sent, or by a combination of the foregoing methods, to abate such abandoned
condition within sixty days either by placing the station in operation in
accordance with this Building Code, adapting and using the building for another
permitted business use, or by razing the service station structure, removing
the pumps and signs, abandoning underground storage tanks in accordance with
accepted safe practice as prescribed by the National Fire Protection
Association in Appendix C. to N. F. P. No. 30, under the supervision of the
Bureau of Fire Prevention and filling depressions to the grade level of the
lot. However, if the station is in operation at the time notice is given and
remains in operation for ninety consecutive days thereafter, the provisions of
this section shall not apply; and if there should be declared a national
emergency which would curtail the operation of motor vehicles or if Council
should determine that there exists a state of general economic depression, the
provisions of this section shall not apply.
(Ord. 40-80. Passed 2-11-80.)
1327.04 REMEDY BY CHIEF ENFORCEMENT OFFICIAL FOR NONCOMPLIANCE.
   Upon failure, neglect or refusal of any owner to comply with the notice to
abate such abandonment, the Chief Enforcement Official shall take such action
as may be necessary to abate such nuisance, including but not limited to
ordering the building razed and the cost certified to the Ross County Auditor
to be placed on the tax duplicate of the owner's property for collection.
(Ord. 40-80. Passed 2-11-80.)
1327.05  APPEALS; HEARING.
   If the owner, upon receiving a notice as set out in Section
1327.03 that the service station is abandoned, is aggrieved by such order and
desires a hearing he may appeal in writing to the Board of Zoning Appeals
within ten days from the service of the order. The Board shall fix a place and
time for a hearing which shall be not less than ten nor more than twenty days
after receipt of the written appeal. The Board, upon the presentation of the
facts by testimony of the parties, who may be represented by counsel and have a
record of the proceedings taken by a reporter, may affirm, modify, revoke or
vacate such order given in the notice in Section
1327.03. During the determination by the Board the order given in the notice
shall be stayed by the Board. Any party to the proceeding, claiming to be
aggrieved by a final order of the Board of Zoning Appeals, may obtain judicial
review thereof by resort to a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance
with the provision of the Ohio R. C. Chapter 2506.
(Ord. 81-70. Passed 11-9-70.)
1327.06  INOPERATIVE SERVICE STATIONS; DEFINED AND REGULATED.
   (a)   "Inoperative service station" means a failure to operate the service
station for a thirty-day period. The parking of motor vehicles upon the
premises of an inoperative service station shall be prohibited and the owner
shall place in the window of such inoperative service station a sign of at
least ten square feet in area notifying the public of this fact. Notwith-
standing, any other provision of the Building Code of the City if the Chief
Enforcement Official finds that such notice is not complied with by the public,
he may order the owner of the premises on which any station is inoperative for
more than thirty days to install fencing or barricades approved by the Chief
Enforcement Official which shall be sufficient to block motor vehicle access to
the property.
(Ord. 40-80. Passed 2-11-80.)
   (b)    The owner of an inoperative service station shall cap underground
storage tanks so that they cannot be opened except by the owner's authorized
personnel. Capping shall be approved by the Fire Department under standards
approved by the National Fire Protection Association.
   (c)    Inoperative service stations shall be maintained in accordance with
the provisions of this Building Code and the owner shall cut all grass and
remove all rubbish and weeds from the premises.
(Ord. 81-70. Passed 11-9-70.)
